(9)  Sporting events conducted by the Eagle Mountain Saginaw Independent School District, or other such public or private educational institution; or 
(10)  A sidewalk procession which observes and complies with traffic regulations and traffic control devices, using that portion of a sidewalk nearest the street, but at no time using more than one-half of the sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-125. - Permit application. 
(a)  Special events . A person desiring to hold a special event shall apply for a permit by filing with the chief of police a written application on a form provided for that purpose. A separate permit is required for each location where a special event will be conducted. The application must be filed not less than 21 days before the first special event is to begin. 
(1)  The chief of police may waive the 21-day filing requirement if the chief of police determines that the application can be processed in fewer than 21 days, taking into consideration the applicable requirements to be imposed, number of agencies and other departments involved, and whether a similar event has previously been permitted. 
(2)  The chief of police shall send to the applicant, by personal delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of whether the 21-day filing requirement will be waived. The applicant may appeal the chief of police's refusal to waive the 21-day filing requirement pursuant to the procedure set forth in section 54-132. 
(b)  Permit fee . An application for a special event or parade permit must be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee, as set forth in the city's fee schedule. The city manager shall have authority to waive application fees for community or non-profit events. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-126. - Contents of application. 
    An application for a special event permit must be signed by the applicant before an officer authorized to administer oaths and contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the applicant and of any other persons responsible for the conduct of the special event; 
(2)  A description of the special event and requested dates and hours of operation for the special event; 
(3)  The estimated number of persons and vehicles to participate in the special event; 
(4)  A sketch showing the area or specific route to be used during the special event (including, if applicable, the starting and termination points), along with the location of proposed structures, stages, tents, fences, barricades, signs, banners, restroom facilities, and loudspeakers and amplifiers; 
(5)  Provisions for parking with a designation of where "no parking" signs will be used; 
(6)  Details of how applicant proposes to provide security; 
(7)  The time and location of street closings, if any are requested; 
(8)  Details of speculated dignitary participation, including the name and office held for each dignitary; 
(9)  A description and the number of animals to be used in the special event, if any; 
(10)  Details of how the applicant will clean up the area used after the special event, if on public property; 
(11)  Proof that the applicant possesses all licenses and permits required by this code or other city ordinance or state law for the conduct of the special event; 
(12)  Proof that the applicant possesses liability insurance in a form and in an amount found to be adequate by the director of finance, taking into consideration the number of people, the risk involved, and the time of the event, to cover the activities licensed herein. Applicant shall name the city and its officers and employees as additional insureds. Applicant shall also provide a certificate of insurance, showing such required insurance, to the director of finance within a reasonable time, no less than 48 hours prior to the scheduled event. If the applicant is of the opinion that the amount or form of insurance is not reasonable, the applicant may appeal pursuant to the procedure set forth in section 54-132; and 
(13)  Any other information requested by the chief of police relevant to the application. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-127. - Departmental notice for special events. 
    Upon receipt of the completed application for a special event permit, the chief of police shall forward a copy of the application to the departments of fire, finance, public works, building inspection, code enforcement and the city manager. If any part of the event is to be held on or adjacent to park property, the chief of police shall also forward a copy of the application to the director of parks and recreation. Each department shall review the application and return it, with any comments, to the chief of police within five working days of receipt, or as otherwise required by the chief of police if the 21-day filing period has been waived pursuant to sections 54-125(a)(1) or 54-132. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-128. - Permit conditions. 
(a)  The department directors and the chief of police may impose conditions and restrictions necessary for the safe and orderly conduct of a special event, to be incorporated into the permit before issuance. 
(b)  The chief of police and department directors shall develop a schedule of actual costs for city personnel, equipment and supplies that are needed in conducting special events and that the applicants are required to reimburse. Once approved and prior to the issuance of a permit, the applicant shall be advised of the required reimbursement to the city. The applicant shall pay such cost or provide security for payment in an amount deemed adequate by the chief of police. In the alternative, if the applicant can provide the required services by other means, approved by the chief of police, the permit may be approved on that basis. 
(c)  The chief of police shall send to the applicant, by personal delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the conditions, restrictions, and costs incorporated into each permit. The applicant may appeal these conditions, restrictions, and costs pursuant to the procedure set forth in section 54-132. 
(d)  To the extent of any conflict, such conditions, restrictions, and costs incorporated into each permit shall supersede the provisions set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-129. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  After reviewing the application and the departmental comments, the chief of police shall issue the permit unless denial is required by the provisions of this article. The chief of police shall give written notice, by personal delivery or certified mail, return receipt requested, of the approval or denial of the special event permit within a period not to exceed ten days from the date the application was submitted. 
(b)  Should the application for a special event permit reveal that the parade route requested will interfere with the orderly flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic, the chief of police shall have authority to establish a reasonable alternate route and regulate the width of the parade. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-130. - Indemnification. 
    An applicant for a special event permit must execute a written agreement to indemnify the city and its officers and employees against all claims of injury or damage to persons or property, whether public or private, arising out of the special event or parade, including without limitation claims of the city for damage to city parks and other city property. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-131. - Denial or revocation. 
(a)  Grounds for denial of a special event permit are as follows, as applicable: 
(1)  A special event permit has been granted for another special event or parade at the same place and time; 
(2)  Another special event has already been permitted at a place and/or time that will directly conflict with the requested special event, and/or there are not sufficient city resources or other comparable resources to reasonably accommodate both events; 
(3)  The proposed special event will unreasonably disrupt the orderly flow of traffic and no other reasonable means of rerouting traffic or otherwise meeting traffic needs is available; 
(4)  The applicant fails to provide for: 
a.  Protection of event participants; 
b.  Public health and sanitation; 
c.  Crowd security, taking into consideration the size of the event; 
d.  Emergency vehicle access; 
e.  Traffic and pedestrian safety; and 
f.  Parking; 
(5)  The applicant fails to comply with, or the proposed special event will violate, a city ordinance or other applicable law, unless the prohibited conduct or activity was specifically permitted pursuant to this article; 
(6)  The applicant makes a false statement of material fact on an application for a special event permit; 
(7)  The applicant fails to provide proof that the applicant possesses a license or permit required by city ordinance or other applicable law for the conduct of all activities included as a part of the special event; 
(8)  The applicant has had a special event permit revoked within the preceding 12 months; 
(9)  The applicant has committed, within the preceding 12 months, a violation of a special event permit or this article; 
(10)  The applicant fails to pay any outstanding costs or damages owed to the city for a past special event; and 
(11)  The applicant has failed to comply with insurance requirements contained in subsection 54-126(11). 
(b)  Grounds for revocation of a special event permit are as follows: 
(1)  The applicant fails to comply with, or the special event is in violation of, a condition or provision of the permit, an ordinance of the city, or any other applicable law, unless the prohibited conduct or activity was specifically permitted pursuant to this article; 
(2)  The permit holder made a false statement of material fact on an application for a special event permit; 
(3)  The special event fails to begin within 30 minutes of the appointed time of commencement, and it would not be reasonable to start the special event late, taking into consideration conditions such as traffic impact, nighttime, parking, city personnel necessary, or other such circumstances; and 
(4)  When, in the judgment of the chief of police, a violation exists that requires immediate abatement because of danger to property, sanitation, or the health or safety of citizens, the chief shall have authority to revoke a permit immediately. 
(c)  [Appeals.] The applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the chief of police to deny or revoke a special event permit pursuant to the procedure set forth in section 54-132. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-132. - Appeal procedure. 
(a)  The appeal procedure in subsection (b) shall be applicable for an appeal from: 
(1)  The chief of police's refusal to waive the 21-day filing requirement for a special event permit, pursuant to subsection 54-125(a)(2); 
(2)  The form and amount of liability insurance required by the director of finance pursuant to subsection 54-126(11); 
(3)  The conditions, restrictions, and costs imposed on a permit for a special event pursuant to subsection 54-128(b); or 
(4)  The denial or revocation of a permit for a special event pursuant to section 54-131. 
(b)  The action of the applicable city staff member shall be final unless the applicant or permit holder, within five days after the receipt of written or oral notice (as required pursuant to this article), files with the city manager a written appeal. The city manager shall, within 72 hours after the appeal is filed, consider all the evidence in support of or against the action appealed and render a decision either sustaining or reversing the decision of the city staff member. The decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(c)  Due to time constraints, there is no appeal for revocation of a permit once the event has begun or has passed its stated starting time. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-133. - Special provisions for special events. 
(a)  Streets and other city property . If the special event requires the use of city streets or other city property, the following conditions shall be applicable: 
(1)  No permanent improvements of any kind shall be placed upon said property by applicant, and any temporary structures shall be removed upon termination of the permit, so that the property permitted shall be returned to the city in the same condition as it existed prior to the granting of the permit by the city; 
(2)  Applicant shall maintain and keep the property clean of any unreasonable accumulation of trash, or any other condition that would be a nuisance to the city; 
(3)  Applicant shall not unduly deny or restrict access to any business or owner in the area; 
(4)  Applicant shall only enter and exit the permitted property by ways approved by the chief of police; 
(5)  If specified in the permit, applicant shall make arrangements to barricade any permitted areas from the general public and erect any safety equipment, including lighting, that is reasonable and necessary and required by the chief of police; 
(6)  Applicant and its agents, employees and contractors shall perform all acts in a safe manner and in compliance with all laws of the city, state and federal government; and 
(7)  Applicant shall obtain the consent and permission of any property owner affected by such permit before requesting the closure of any streets, rights-of-way, or other city property, and indemnify the city, its officers and employees, from any claim filed by owners of property affected by the closure of the streets, rights-of-way, or other city property. 
(b)  Parking . The city shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary as determined by the police department based on pedestrian and traffic safety, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a street or highway or part thereof adjacent to the site of the special event or parade. The city shall post signs, at the applicant's cost, indicating that it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in such areas. 
(c)  Trailers . Trailers or other vehicles may be temporarily occupied as living quarters at the site of a special event, provided the trailers have self-contained sanitation facilities or are connected to approved sanitary disposal systems. Such vehicles and trailers shall be parked at least 300 feet or more from any developed residential district and located so as not to impede vehicular or pedestrian traffic. Compliance with zoning ordinance section 8-7 will be required. 
(d)  Amusement rides . Rides and/or other attractions associated with special events shall conform to statutory rules and regulations set forth in Chapter 2151 of the Texas Occupations Code, as amended, designated the "Amusement Ride Safety Inspection and Insurance Act." 
(e)  Tents and temporary structures . Any use of a tent, canopy, or temporary structure, including a stage, shall meet the requirements of the uniform fire code, except that a separate permit is not required when a special event or parade permit has been obtained. Fire lanes for emergency equipment must be provided and the site prepared in a manner so as not to be a fire hazard as determined by the fire chief. The tent or temporary structure must also be properly anchored and supported for purposes of public safety. 
(f)  Food service . Where food service is provided, said operation shall be in compliance with all provisions of applicable laws and ordinances concerning food service, including without limitation applicable provisions of the Texas Health and Safety Code, as amended. 
(g)  Sanitary facilities . The chief of police and the director of parks and recreation in park areas, with advice from the Tarrant County Department of Health, shall establish the requirements for portable type sanitary facilities based on the estimated number of people, other available facilities in the area, and the term of the event. 
(h)  Animals . Applicant shall make arrangements to remove all waste from animals used in any special event or parade. Should animals be kept within the city limits at night, they shall be kept at least 300 feet or more from any developed residential district. Animals in parks are subject to park rules. 
(i)  Water usage . Any special event or parade requiring the use of water from the city water system must coordinate with the utility department to obtain a temporary meter. Deposit for the meter and payment for water used shall be in accordance with ordinances of the city. 
(j)  Solid waste dumpsters . The director of public works shall establish the requirements for solid waste dumpsters based on the estimated number of people, type of events, other facilities in the area and term of the event. 
(k)  Loudspeakers and amplifiers . The use of loudspeakers and amplifiers for special events or parades shall be in accordance with sections 30-131 and 30-132 of this Code. 
(l)  Miscellaneous . An applicant shall comply with the following special requirements: 
(1)  Notify any residents whose access to their own property will be limited or restricted by reason of the special event or parade; and 
(2)  Meet with the chief of police, or designated agent, on a timely basis prior to the special event or parade, at a time and place designated by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 54-134. - Offense and penalty. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if that person: 
(1)  Commences or conducts a special event without a permit; or 
(2)  Fails to comply with any requirement or provision for a special event pursuant to this article; or 
(3)  Obstructs, impedes or interferes with any special event, or with any person, vehicle or animal participating in a special event. 
(b)  If conduct that would otherwise violate this section consists of speech or other communication, in a gathering with others to hear or observe such speech or communication, or in a gathering with others to picket or otherwise express in a nonviolent manner a position on social, economic, political, or religious questions, the person may not be arrested or cited unless the person has first been ordered to move, disperse, or otherwise remedy the violation. 
(c)  Any person who violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(d)  Each day that any violation hereof continues shall be deemed to constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Chapter 58 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 30; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Election required for sale of public park or square, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 253.001; parks and wildlife, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 1.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - City youth programs standards of care adopted. 
    The city council hereby adopts the City of Saginaw Youth Programs Standards of Care for providing basic child care regulations for day camp activities operated by the city recreation and community services department. As required by V.T.C.A., Human Resources Code § 42.041(b)(14), the standards adopted by this ordinance include staffing ratios; minimum staff qualifications; minimum facility, health, and safety standards; and mechanisms for monitoring and enforcing the adopted local standards. A substantial copy of the City of Saginaw Youth Programs Standards of Care is attached to Ord. No. 2010-05 and incorporated herein for all intents and purposes as exhibit "A" and shall be available on the city's web site under the "Recreation" subheading. 
(Ord. No. 2007-06, § 1, 3-6-07; Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 3-4-08; Ord. No. 2009-05, § 1, 3-17-09; Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 4-6-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-06, § 1, adopted March 6, 2007, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as § 58-1 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 58-2-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADVISORY RECREATION AND PARKS BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-131 et seq. 

Sec. 58-31. - Created; compensation; qualifications. 
    There is hereby created an advisory recreation and parks board of the city, consisting of seven members to be appointed by the city council, said members to serve without compensation. A member must be a qualified voter in the city and shall be subject to removal at any time by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 16-16) 
Sec. 58-32. - Terms of members. 
    Members of said board shall be appointed to places one through seven, respectively. Members shall be appointed to the odd-numbered places in odd-numbered years and to the even-numbered places in even-numbered years, each to serve a term of two years from May 1 of the year of appointment until their successor is appointed in May of the succeeding odd-numbered to even-numbered year, respectively. 
(Code 1987, § 16-17) 
Sec. 58-33. - Duties. 
(a)  It will be the duty of the advisory recreation and parks board to: 
(1)  Make recommendations and suggestions to the city council, through the city manager or his designated representative, on the use, control and regulation of the parks and recreation centers and facilities of the city; 
(2)  Review existing facilities to determine the need for expansion of the parks and recreation centers of the city; 
(3)  Administer all gifts, bequests and legacies made to the city for park and recreation purposes for the benefit of the park and recreation system, subject to review and audit by the city manager and city council. 
(b)  Administration of regular budget items for park and recreation purposes shall be under the control of the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 16-18) 
Sec. 58-34. - Procedures. 
    The board shall elect annually from its members a chairperson and a vice chairperson. Four members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The board shall prescribe its own rules as to meeting times and places and procedures to be followed at the meetings. 
(Code 1987, § 16-19) 
Sec. 58-35. - Authority. 
    The board is to be an advisory board only as the name implies. All decisions and actions by the board shall be subject to review by the city manager, who shall keep the council advised as he deems necessary or appropriate. Any decision or action by the board shall be subject to veto by either the city manager or the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 16-20) 
Secs. 58-36-58-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK, PLAYGROUND AND RECREATION AREA RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 58-61. - Activities restricted; authority; special permits; overnight camping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any individual or group of individuals to participate in any activity on any park or playground area when such activity will create a danger to the public or may be considered a public nuisance. The city manager or parks and recreation director (designated by the city manager) may designate particular locations within the park and playground areas for specific activities. When deemed necessary, the city manager may limit the conduct of such activities by the issuance of special permits upon application, which permits shall set out particular conditions under which activity is permitted. Overnight camping is prohibited on any park property except by special permit issued for such activity on special occasions. 
(Code 1987, § 16-21) 
Sec. 58-62. - Restricted areas; hours posted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any portion of a park or recreation area which is designated as restricted or to enter any area during the hours of the day when said area is not open to the public or to enter at any time any park and recreation area which is closed for the season. Hours during which the area is open to the public shall be posted by the parks and recreation director. 
(Code 1987, § 16-22) 
Sec. 58-63. - Concessions; granted by contract. 
    The city council may from time to time, upon the recommendation of the city manager, grant concessions for the operation of amusements, refreshment stands and related concessionaire facilities for operation in city parks and playgrounds. Any such concessions shall be granted upon a written contract detailing the privileges, duties and responsibilities of the concessionaire and providing adequate protection for the city and its citizens. 
(Code 1987, § 16-23) 
Sec. 58-64. - Written agreement or permit required for selling food, merchandise; application. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer to sell any food, drinks, confections, merchandise or services in any park or playground unless such person has a written agreement or a permit issued by the city permitting the sale of such items in the park or playground. Application for such permit shall be made to the parks and recreation director. 
(Code 1987, § 16-24) 
Sec. 58-65. - Parking. 
    Where vehicle parking lots or areas have been set aside in a park in the city, no vehicle shall be driven over or across the curbs, sidewalks, grass or lawn within such park but shall be parked in such parking lots or areas and not otherwise. 
(Code 1987, § 16-25) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 58-66. - Use of vehicles; transportation of goods; riding horses or other animals. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive or propel any vehicle over or through any park or playground except along or upon park drives, parkways or park boulevards or to drive or propel along or over any park, parkway or park boulevard any heavily laden vehicle or vehicles carrying merchandise, goods, material or rubbish or any market wagon, dirt cart, moving van or truck. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or to lead or drive any horse or other animal over or through any park or playground except along and upon the designated paths. 
(Code 1987, § 16-26) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, ch. 6; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 58-67. - Advertising; signs; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful to place or erect any structure, sign, bulletin board, post, pole or advertising device of any kind whatsoever in any park or playground or to attach to any tree, shrub, fence, railing, post or structure within any park or playground. Provided, however, the parks and recreation director may permit the erection of temporary decorations on occasions of public celebrations or holidays. 
(Code 1987, § 16-27) 
Cross reference- Sign code, § 10-381 et seq.; signs generally, ch. 78. 
Sec. 58-68. - Destruction of park property. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove, destroy, mutilate or deface any structure, monument, statue, vase, fountain, wall, fence, railing, vehicle, bench or other property in any park or playground. 
(Code 1987, § 16-28) 
Sec. 58-69. - Injuring or destroying vegetation or structures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, break, deface or in any way injure the trees, shrubs, plants, grass, turf, seats, fountains, fences, structures, improvements, ornaments or property within or upon any of the parks and playgrounds. 
(Code 1987, § 16-29) 
Sec. 58-70. - Teasing or molesting animals. 
    It shall be unlawful to tease, annoy, molest, catch, injure or kill or throw any stone, object or missile of any kind at or strike with a stick, object or weapon any animal, bird, fowl or fish in any park or playground. 
(Code 1987, § 16-30) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, ch. 6. 
Sec. 58-71. - Disturbing the peace; profanity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continue at any recreation facility any loud unreasonable or unusual noise or any noise which disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others. It shall be unlawful for any person to use boisterous, insulting, profane language or to conduct oneself in a disorderly, lewd, obscene or lascivious manner in any park or recreation area. 
(Code 1987, § 16-31) 
Secs. 58-72-58-74. - Reserved. 
Sec. 58-75. - Dog park rules and regulations. 
(a)  Dog park hours are from dawn to dusk. 
(b)  All dogs must have current rabies tags and be free of any contagious diseases. 
(c)  Dogs to remain leashed in entry/exit area. 
(d)  Dogs displaying aggressive behavior shall be leashed and removed immediately. 
(e)  Dogs must be in view and voice control of their owners/handlers at all times. 
(f)  Owners/handlers must carry a leash at all times for their dog(s). 
(g)  Maximum of two dogs per owner/handler. 
(h)  No unaccompanied children under 13 years old allowed. 
(i)  Dogs four months of age or less are prohibited. 
(j)  Dogs in heat are prohibited. 
(k)  No food or drinks (human or canine) except bottled water allowed in park. 
(l)  Dogs less than 25 lbs. are not allowed in the large dog area. Dogs over 25 lbs. are not allowed in the small dog area. 
(m)  No bicycles, rollerblades, skateboards or motorized vehicles allowed in park except maintenance vehicles. 
(n)  Owners/handlers must clean up their dog's waste. 
(o)  Owners/handlers shall report dog bites or dog scratches of humans to animal services at 817-232-0311 (police dispatch). 
(p)  Your use of this park is at your own risk. The City of Saginaw is not responsible for accidents, injury, or other damages of any kind. 
(q)  The city manager is hereby authorized to post additional dog park rules necessary to protect the public's welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-3-15) 
Chapter 62 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-131 et seq.; zoning, § 7-1 et seq. 

Secs. 62-31-62-32. - Reserved. 
Sec. 62-33. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person or persons aggrieved by any decision of the planning and zoning commission shall have the right of appeal to the city council by filing written notice of appeal, duly verified and pointing out the claims of illegality, within seven days following the announcement and filing of the decision of the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  The following types of decisions by the planning and zoning commission shall be automatically appealed to the city council for its consideration, without the necessity of notice by any party, and such planning and zoning commission decision shall not become effective unless and until confirmed and ratified by the city council after hearing: 
(1)  Any decision by the planning and zoning commission requiring amendment of the zoning ordinance; 
(2)  Any decision of the planning and zoning commission giving final approval to a subdivision plat for recordation; 
(3)  Any decision of the planning and zoning commission giving final approval to a planned unit development; and 
(4)  Any decision of the planning and zoning commission granting a variance, either temporary or permanent, from the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1987, § 16.5-23) 
Chapter 66 - POLICE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 66-26. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the police department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 2-6-01) 
Sec. 66-27. - Appointment of officers and employees. 
    The city manager shall appoint the chief of police. The department shall be composed of the chief of police, and such other officers, patrolmen, and employees as the chief of police may determine, with the approval of the city manager and subject to a budget approved by the city council. The chief of police and all other police officers, must hold an appropriate license or certification as required by state law. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 2-6-01) 
Sec. 66-28. - Chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall have direction and control of the police department subject to the supervision of the city manager, federal and state laws, and rules, regulations and ordinances adopted by the city council. The chief of police shall have the authority to promulgate rules, regulations, and procedures for the operation of the police department and conduct of personnel. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 2-6-01) 
Sec. 66-29. - Power and duties of police officers. 
    The chief of police and all police officers have the powers, rights, and jurisdiction as prescribed by state law. It shall be their duty to prevent the commission of offenses against the laws of the state and against the ordinances of the city; to obey, observe, and enforce all such laws, ordinances, and regulations; to detect and arrest offenders of all such laws, ordinances, and regulations; to preserve the good order of the city; and to secure the inhabitants of the city from violence, injury, and property damage. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 2-6-01) 
Sec. 66-30. - Police reserve force. 
    Members of the police reserve force shall be appointed by the chief of police. Reserve officers will be held to the same training and licensing standards as full-time members of the department. Upon appointment by the chief of police, members of the reserve police force must be approved by a simple majority of the city council before acting as a peace officer. 
(Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 2-6-01) 
Chapter 70 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 14. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARAGE SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-31. - Definition. 
    Garage sales as used in this article shall mean occasional sales at retail, by residential owners or occupants, conducted in the garage, patio, driveway or yard of the residential premises occupied by the person holding the sale, for the purpose of disposing of surplus personal property accumulated incidentally in the regular course of residential occupancy. 
(Code 1987, § 12-41; 98-1, § 1, 1-6-98) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-32. - Restrictions. 
    Garage sales shall be subject to the following restrictions, rules and regulations: 
(1)  Such sale shall be conducted only by an owner or occupant of such residential premises where the sale is to be held, or by members of the household or family of such owner or occupant, and no permit shall be issued to any person who holds himself out as being habitually in the business of selling such property at retail. 
(2)  Such sales shall not exceed two in any one calendar year on the same premises, and shall not extend in duration for more than three consecutive days for any one sale. 
(3)  No new merchandise acquired solely for the purpose of resale on the premises shall be sold at such occasional sales. Garage sales shall be restricted to surplus personal property accumulated as an incident to residential occupancy of the premises. 
(4)  Nothing herein shall prevent not more than three families cooperating in holding a joint garage sale on the residential premises of any one of them, provided all such joint participants are named in the application and permit, and only property permissible in a separate sale by each of such families is offered for sale. 
(5)  Permit therefor shall be first obtained prior to the sale by application in writing on forms provided by the city, at a cost of $5.00. 
(6)  The permit shall be displayed on the premises during the sale. 
(7)  Signage shall be limited to signs issued by the city. With each garage sale permit the applicant will be issued a total of three signs. One yard sign to be displayed on the property of the garage sale and two directional signs to aid the public in locating the sale. These signs are strictly prohibited from being located on utility poles. Signs may be displayed 24 hours prior to actual sale, and must be removed prior to 8:00 p.m. the last day of the permitted sale. 
(Code 1987, § 12-45; Ord. No. 98-1, § 3, 1-6-98) 
Sec. 70-33. - Non-profit and charitable organization sales. 
    The requirements set forth in this section shall apply only to garage sales conducted by non-profit and charitable organizations: 
(1)  Such sales shall not exceed two in a calendar year by any one non-profit or charitable organization. 
(2)  No more than four non-profit or charitable organization garage sales may be conducted on the same property in any one calendar year. 
(3)  A garage sale conducted pursuant to this section shall not exceed one day in duration. 
(4)  Notwithstanding the requirements of division 2 of this article, an application for a garage sale permit under this section must be submitted to the office of the city secretary at least seven days prior to the proposed date of the sale. There shall be no cost associated with an application for a garage sale permit under this section. 
(5)  The application must be signed by the owner of the property indicating that the owner has granted the non-profit or charitable organization permission to conduct the sale on the property and acknowledging that no more than four non-profit or charitable organization garage sales per calendar year may be conducted on the property. 
(6)  Only one sign advertising the garage sale is permitted and the sign must be located on the property where the sale will be conducted. The sign shall be issued by the city. 
(7)  No structure, sales table, or sales item may be located within any street right-of-way or be placed in such a manner as to obstruct traffic visibility. 
(8)  Vehicles may not be parked in such a manner as to obstruct the orderly flow of vehicular traffic on public streets. 
(9)  All items associated with the garage sale must be removed from public display on the property by 8:00 p.m. on the date of the garage sale. 
(10)  Non-profit and charitable organizations may not conduct garage sales at apartment complex properties within the city. 
(11)  Non-profit and charitable organizations shall not be required to comply with the requirements set forth in section 70-32. 
(12)  To the extent of a conflict with the language in subsection 8-7 C. of the city's zoning ordinance, governing permitted special events, this section shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2010-07, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Cross reference- Temporary uses and special events, app. A, § 8-7. 
Secs. 70-34-70-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 70-51. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be permissible to conduct garage sales on residential zoned premises in the city only pursuant to permit first obtained from the city manager or his designated representative, and only in accordance with the rules, regulations and restrictions herein provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to conduct any garage sale, as herein defined, within the city without a permit or in violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 12-42; Ord. No. 98-1, § 2, 1-6-98) 
Sec. 70-52. - Permit application; fee. 
    A permit shall be obtained by application in writing on form provided by the city at a cost of $5.00. The permit shall be obtained at least 72 hours prior to the sale. 
(Code 1987, § 12-43) 
Sec. 70-53. - Violation. 
    A violation of any provision of this division shall be a misdemeanor punishable upon conviction by fine in any amount not to exceed $200.00. 
(Ord. No. 98-1, § 5, 1-6-98) 
Secs. 70-54-70-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - JUNK AND SECONDHAND GOODS DEALERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 30; junked motor vehicles, § 30-91 et seq.; burning of junked vehicles and parts prohibited, § 34-184. 
State Law reference- Automobile wrecking and salvage yards, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 396. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junk shall have its ordinary and accepted meaning, and in addition shall also include any and all of the following scrap materials, to wit: iron, tin, brass, copper, lead, zinc and any and all other metals or their alloys, bones, rags, cloth, rubber, rope, tin foil, bottles, cotton and any and all other fabrics; and/or any and all of the following used or secondhand items and products, to wit: mechanical tools, garden tools and/or utensils, plumbing fixtures, appliances, fittings, pipes and/or supplies, electrical fixtures, appliances, fittings and/or supplies, gas fixtures, fittings, pipes, appliances and/or supplies, water heaters, lawn hose, harness, doors, window sash, glass, mantels and/or parts thereof, automobile parts and/or accessories, and/or tires and/or tubes. 
    Junk dealer shall have its ordinary and accepted meaning, and in addition shall also mean and include any person engaged in any of the following: collecting, handling, buying and selling of scrap materials of iron, tin, brass, zinc and/or other metals and their alloys, and/or bones, rags, cloth, rubber, rope, tin foil, bottles and/or cotton and other fabrics, and/or used or secondhand plumbing fixtures, pipe, appliances, fittings, mechanical tools, garden tools and utensils, electrical fixtures, fittings and/or appliances, gas fixtures, fittings and/or appliances, water heaters, lawn hose, harness, doors, window sash, glass, mantels or parts thereof, automobiles purchased for the purpose of dismantling, automobile parts and/or accessories, tires and/or tubes. 
    Junk dealers, junk dealer, dealers in junk, secondhand dealers and dealers in secondhand goods are all terms that are used synonymously in this article unless the context clearly indicates an express different intention. 
    Secondhand dealer shall have its ordinary and accepted meaning, and in addition shall also mean and include any person engaged in the sale or traffic in, collecting, handling, buying, trading and/or selling of any of the following: used or secondhand wearing apparel, hats, shoes, overcoats and/or other kinds of clothing, watches, jewelry and/or other objects fabricated from precious or semi-precious metals, diamonds and/or other gems and/or precious stones, luggage, musical instruments, shotguns, rifles, revolvers and/or other firearms, knives and/or other weapons, and/or any and all other kinds of used or secondhand goods, wares and/or merchandise which are handled by secondhand dealers and pawnbrokers in their usual course of trade. 
(Code 1987, § 12-61) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-82. - Records required. 
    All licensed junk dealers and all licensed secondhand dealers shall at all times keep records of all business transactions within the city including the following information as to any junk or secondhand article purchased by or deposited with him for any purpose within the city: 
(1)  The name, address, sex, age, residence, race and signature of the person selling or depositing such junk or secondhand article, and the license number of the automobile in which it was delivered. 
(2)  An accurate description of the junk or secondhand articles purchased or deposited, the date and time of purchase or deposit thereof and the number of an identifying tag placed on the junk lot or secondhand items which will correlate them to the written record hereby required, and the address where purchased. 
(3)  Unless the licensee is personally acquainted with the seller or depositer of such junk or secondhand items sufficiently to thereafter positively identify such seller, some certain identification recordation, such as a driver's license number, social security number or similar information, which the licensee or his agent feels is authentic. If no other reliable record is offered, then the licensee shall require the ink thumbprint of the seller on such written record. 
(Code 1987, § 12-69) 
Sec. 70-83. - Retention period, exception. 
    Each lot of junk and each secondhand article, except scrap of nonprecious metals, tin foil, bones, rags and bottles, shall be retained by the junk dealer or secondhand dealer in its original form, with identifying tag thereto attached, for a period of at least 15 days from its purchase or deposit. During this time no part of such junk or secondhand items shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed or removed from the place of business of such dealer. This provision for 15 days' retention shall not apply to goods on consignment by local residents who reside within the city nor to goods purchased or on consignment from wholesale dealers regularly engaged in the business of selling secondhand goods to retail dealers for resale, and who have a fixed place of business where they can be readily contacted. 
(Code 1987, § 12-70) 
Sec. 70-84. - Inspection. 
    The records herein required to be kept, and each and every article purchased by or for, or deposited with any junk dealer or secondhand dealer shall at all reasonable times be open to inspection by the chief of police or any police officer of the city. No search warrant or other writ of any kind shall be necessary for such inspection. 
(Code 1987, § 12-71) 
Sec. 70-85. - Tags required. 
    At all time during the period of retention specified in section 70-83, each lot, sack, barrel or box of junk, and each article of secondhand goods, purchased by or deposited with a junk dealer or secondhand dealer, shall have attached to it a legible identifying tag to correlate it with the record of its purchase by or deposit with such dealer. 
(Code 1987, § 12-72) 
Sec. 70-86. - Removal of identifying marks prohibited. 
    No junk dealer or secondhand dealer shall purchase or have in his possession or receive in pledge or on deposit for any purpose any article of junk or secondhand article from which the manufacturer's serial number or brand name or mark has been removed or obliterated. 
(Code 1987, § 12-73) 
Sec. 70-87. - Minor's parent's permission required. 
    No junk dealer or secondhand dealer shall purchase or have in his possession or on deposit for any purpose or receive in pledge from any minor any junk or secondhand item or article unless he receives and has on file for inspection by any police officer of the city a written statement from the parent or guardian of such minor that such transaction has taken place with such parent or guardian's full knowledge and consent with the name, address and telephone number of the parent or guardian displayed on such consent form. 
(Code 1987, § 12-74) 
Sec. 70-88. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a junk dealer or secondhand dealer within the corporate limits of the city between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., of the following morning or at any time on a Sunday. 
(Code 1987, § 12-75) 
Secs. 70-89-70-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 70-101. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer or secondhand dealer to transact or engage in business within the city unless such dealer has obtained an annual license therefor from the city in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1987, § 12-62) 
Sec. 70-102. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a license shall be in writing, signed and sworn to by the applicant and delivered to the city secretary. The application shall contain the name, address and other reasonable information necessary to identify the applicant and such applicant's place of business. If it is a partnership, firm or corporation, the application shall show the individual names and addresses of the partners or offices. 
(b)  The application shall contain the following statement: "It is expressly agreed that the license hereby applied for, and the licensee if same is granted, shall be subject to all the provisions and regulations of Chapter 70, Article III of the Saginaw City Code and any other ordinances of the said city relating to junk, junk dealers and secondhand dealers." 
(c)  If the applicant does not have a fixed place of business within the city, the application shall also contain the following statement: "It is expressly agreed that if this license applied for is granted, the applicant-licensee consents to the inspection of its records and goods, wares and merchandise at its fixed place of business at any reasonable time by the chief of police of the city or his designated representative, without the necessity of any search warrant or other writ of any kind." 
(Code 1987, § 12-63) 
Sec. 70-103. - Fee for license. 
    Each applicant shall pay an annual license fee in advance of $25.00 which shall be for the calendar year or part thereof. The license shall be renewable each calendar year upon payment of the same fee. 
(Code 1987, § 12-64) 
Sec. 70-104. - Issuance. 
    If the city secretary finds the application in proper form, he shall issue such license upon payment of the fee. 
(Code 1987, § 12-65) 
Sec. 70-105. - License available for inspection. 
    Every junk dealer and secondhand dealer while engaged in the prosecution of his business within the city shall have his license available for inspection at all times. 
(Code 1987, § 12-66) 
Sec. 70-106. - License not to be used by persons other than applicant. 
    It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer or secondhand dealer to knowingly assign or permit his license to be used by any other person. It shall be unlawful for any person to use the license of another to transact any business within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 12-67) 
Sec. 70-107. - Revocation of license. 
    Conviction for violating any of the provisions of this article shall be sufficient cause for the cancellation of the license, upon the recommendation of the chief of police and within the discretion of the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 12-68) 
Chapter 74 - SENIOR CITIZENS CENTER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Membership. 
    Membership in the city senior citizens center shall be open to all residents of the city, and nonresidents in the surrounding area desiring to participate therein, who have attained their 55th birthday, and to spouses of any such members, regardless of age. No membership fee shall be required for participation in the center. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-1) 
Sec. 74-2. - General meetings. 
(a)  The entire membership of the senior citizens center shall meet once a month in general session at the log cabin, at a regular designated time, to exchange information related to center services and conduct any necessary business. 
(b)  The chairperson of the advisory board, hereinafter provided, may call other meetings of the total membership provided five days' notice is posted on the official bulletin board at the center. 
(c)  All called meetings of the total membership must discuss only that business which has been announced in the notice. 
(d)  All meetings shall be conducted according to Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-2) 
Sec. 74-3. - Amendments. 
    Amendments to the rules and regulations herein set forth must be approved by the general membership and presented for final adoption by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-3) 
Sec. 74-4. - Standing rules. 
(a)  The director of the center shall be an ex officio member of the advisory board and of all committees, including the nominating committee. The director's presence is in an advisory capacity and without voting privileges. 
(b)  The use of profane and vulgar language at the center is strictly forbidden. 
(c)  Drinking of intoxicating beverages or the presence of the same on the premises is prohibited. Anyone whose behavior or actions suggest drug or alcohol abuse shall be asked to leave the premises. 
(d)  General rowdiness, scuffling or shoving shall not be permitted on the center premises. 
(e)  Use of the office phone shall be limited to cases of emergency. 
(f)  Any person who restricts, threatens or abuses any other individual, either physically or verbally, or who destroys center property or equipment, will be subject to suspension of all privileges. 
(g)  The center director shall have authority to suspend any person from one to ten days for consistent violation of center rules and regulations. The director will report such actions to the advisory board, and the following actions must follow any suspension of an individual from center premises or activities: 
(1)  A letter must be sent to the person involved stating the length of suspension, date of reinstatement and description of unacceptable conduct, to be sent by certified mail, with return receipt requested. 
(2)  The letter may be handed to the offending party or parties, if it can be done so privately in the director's office, but two witnesses must be present at such delivery. 
(3)  Enforcement of the suspension, if necessary, shall be handled by local law enforcement officers, by placing a nonemergency call for assistance, showing the reporting officer the letter, and requesting that the offender be escorted from the premises. 
(h)  Any time an individual is physically restricted, threatened or abused at the center, the police must be called. A police report shall be completed and copies submitted to the center director and advisory board chairperson. 
(i)  The membership may have fund raising projects to provide items or special projects not covered by the city budget, provided such projects are recommended by the advisory board and approved by the general membership, and are coordinated through the staff so that there will be no conflict with planned programs, and provided such fund raising effort is acceptable to the city council. 
(j)  Funds raised through such projects must be handled by the treasurer's office and used only for specific needs or activities recommended and approved by the advisory board. 
(k)  Each six months the advisory board shall appoint a committee to review the records of the center's funds, and to satisfy said committee that bank reconciliations have been correctly accomplished. The treasurer will report the findings of said committee to the general membership at the next regular meeting thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-4) 
Secs. 74-5-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-131 et seq. 

Sec. 74-31. - Organization. 
(a)  Membership. The center advisory board shall consist of such number of persons as the membership shall determine, not less than nine, elected by the membership in a general meeting, or a special meeting called for that purpose. Board members must be regularly participating members in the center and over 55 years of age. 
(b)  Meetings. The advisory board shall meet at least five days prior to each general meeting of the center, to organize an agenda for the general membership meeting and to conduct any other business deemed necessary. It may have other meetings as it shall determine necessary. 
(c)  Removal from membership. Any member of the center advisory board who is absent for three consecutive board meetings shall be automatically dropped, and the replacement shall be named by a nominating committee for approval at the next general meeting of the membership. 
(d)  Election of members. Advisory board members shall be elected in May of each year and shall serve for a term of office of one year. In electing board members, the membership shall elect a chairperson, vice chairperson, secretary, treasurer and chairpersons for each of the following standing committees: 
(1)  Nutrition and food service. 
(2)  Program and recreational activities. 
(3)  Outreach and inreach. 
(4)  Newsletter. 
(5)  Volunteers. 
(e)  Terms of office. Terms of office shall be one year. No officer or standing committee chairperson shall serve more than two consecutive terms, or two years, in the same position. Any person filling a vacated office which has more than six months left will be considered as having a full term. One year must expire before a former officer or committee chairperson shall be eligible for that position again. 
(f)  Committees. The advisory board shall designate other committees necessary to help discharge its responsibilities. Each committee shall consist of not less than three persons. All recommendations of committees shall be presented to the advisory board for its approval. 
(g)  Compensation. No office or committee chairperson shall receive compensation for service in performance of duties of their office. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-11) 
Sec. 74-32. - Responsibilities. 
(a)  The center advisory board's mission is to provide means by which the membership of the center may have input into the planning of senior citizens service to: 
(1)  Assist staff in providing meaningful and constructive activities to meet the expressed needs by helping set objectives and evaluate effectiveness of center programs; 
(2)  Be aware as elected representatives of the needs and desires of the center participants; to assist staff in establishing clear lines of communication between city council, staff and the center participants; and 
(3)  Assist in providing opportunities that will prolong the independent years of the individuals in the membership. 
(b)  The center advisory board shall also consult with the center staff and participate in matters of: 
(1)  Decor and furnishings at the center; 
(2)  Days and hours of center operation; 
(3)  Setting of fee schedules for senior citizens activities; 
(4)  General type of menus, etc.; and 
(5)  Programs and activities for senior citizens. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-12) 
Sec. 74-33. - Duties of the board chairperson. 
    The chairperson of advisory board shall preside at all meetings of both the board and the general membership, shall call all special meetings of the membership or board, giving proper notice, and shall serve on all committees as an ex officio member, with the exception of the nominating committee. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-13) 
Sec. 74-34. - Duties of the board vice chairperson. 
    The vice chairperson shall preside and perform the duties of the chairperson in his or her absence, shall keep attendance records of all meetings, and shall perform all other duties assigned by the chairperson. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-14) 
Sec. 74-35. - Duties of the board secretary. 
    The secretary shall keep minutes of all general meetings and all advisory board meetings in a book or books provided for that purpose by the city, and shall perform such other secretarial duties as may arise from time to time. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-15) 
Sec. 74-36. - Duties of the board treasurer. 
    The treasurer shall collect and keep accurate and current records in a book provided by the city and kept at the center of all monies donated, collected or disbursed from the general membership fund, provide current monthly reports to the general membership at the regular monthly meetings, and immediately deposit all monies for the general membership in a center bank account set up and approved by the center advisory board, making disbursements by check only and signed by both the treasurer and another officer of the advisory board. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-16) 
Secs. 74-37-74-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GRIEVANCE COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-131 et seq. 

Sec. 74-61. - Composition; procedure for handling grievances. 
(a)  All grievances of the membership brought to the attention of the advisory board shall be referred in writing to a grievance committee for its discussion and recommendation back to the advisory board. 
(b)  The grievance committee shall be composed of the advisory board chairperson, center director and two members not on the center advisory board but chosen by the advisory board. 
(c)  A member requesting consideration of a grievance shall meet with the committee, and the committee shall determine any further action necessary. 
(d)  Legitimate grievances or suggestions that benefit the entire membership shall be handled by the advisory board and, if necessary, presented to the general membership. 
(Code 1987, § 17.5-26) 
Chapter 82 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; businesses, ch. 14; environment, ch. 30; spill or escape of hazardous materials, § 34-3; health and sanitation, ch. 42; health regulations for liquid waste, § 42-171 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Garbage, refuse and other waste, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.013. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Franchise agreement. 
(a)  The present existence of a franchise agreement between the city and Trinity Waste Systems, Inc., for the exclusive right of Trinity Waste Systems, Inc. to engage in the business of collecting and disposing of garbage, trash, refuse, brush, debris and other wastes from premises within the city is hereby confirmed. The exclusive existing franchise agreement is set forth in appendix C to this Code, and is adopted by reference as a part of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of regularly collecting and disposing of garbage, trash, refuse, brush, debris and/or wastes, whether residential, business, commercial, industrial or otherwise, from premises within the city without first obtaining a franchise agreement from the city to engage in the business. 
(Code 1987, § 9-1) 
Sec. 82-2. - Mandatory collection by franchise. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises within the city to employ any person other than a licensed franchise holder from the city to regularly collect and/or dispose of any garbage, trash, refuse, brush, debris or other wastes, whether residential, business, commercial, industrial or otherwise, from the premises of such owner or occupant within the city. In view of the existing exclusive franchise agreement above described, it is therefore presently unlawful for any owner or occupant of premises within the city to contract for the collection and/or disposal of garbage originating from premises within the city with any person except Trinity Waste Systems, Inc. 
(Code 1987, § 9-2) 
Sec. 82-3. - Application of chapter. 
    This chapter applies to the regular and periodic collection and disposal of garbage, trash, refuse, brush, debris and wastes, and is not intended to prohibit or require a permit for the occasional hauling of trash, brush, debris, etc., by a maintenance person or employee, or by the owner or occupant of premises, in connection with an occasional cleanup of premises. This chapter shall also apply to any roll-off refuse container or dumpster, including those used by maintenance persons, employees, contractors, or owner or occupants of premises in connection with construction, repair, renovation, or demolition of improvements to realty. 
(Code 1987, § 9-8; Ord. No. 2002-10, § II, 7-16-02) 
Secs. 82-4-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRANSPORTING PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 

Sec. 82-31. - Permit for transporting solid wastes. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises within the city to regularly or periodically collect and transport from such premises any garbage, trash, refuse, brush, debris and/or wastes of any kind, for disposal elsewhere, separate and apart from the premises, unless such owner or occupant shall first make application and payment and obtain from the city a permit to engage in self-collection and self-disposal of garbage, trash, refuse, brush, debris and/or wastes of any kind from such premises. 
(Code 1987, § 9-3) 
Sec. 82-32. - Application. 
    Application for the self-collection and self-disposal permit referred to in the preceding section shall be made in writing to the city secretary, and signed by the applicant. The application shall fully describe the premises from which self-collection and self-disposal are to be made, the nature and probable quantity of garbage, trash, refuse, wastes, etc., for collection and disposal, the vehicle or vehicles to be used in the collection and disposal, the nature of containers of the substances for collection and disposal, including the safeguards to prevent spillage and pollution, the probable frequency of transporting for disposal, and the site or location where final disposition is to be accomplished. 
(Code 1987, § 9-4) 
Sec. 82-33. - Issuance of permit. 
    If the city secretary determines that the provisions and equipment for such self-collection and self-disposal are adequate to safeguard the health, cleanliness and safety of the city, then the city secretary shall issue a permit for such self-collection and self-disposal of garbage, trash, wastes, etc., upon payment of the proper fee as set forth in section 82-34. The city secretary or his designated representative shall be given access to the premises in question and the equipment to be used, for the purpose of inspection and approval. The permit shall be good for the calendar year during which issued, and shall be subject to renewal annually, upon payment of proper fee therefor. A separate permit shall be required for each separate property, even if owned by the same person or used by the same occupant. Property shall be deemed separate if it is a separate lot, tract or parcel of land by recorded subdivision, or separate by usage, or separately rendered or assessed for tax purposes. 
(Code 1987, § 9-5) 
Sec. 82-34. - Fee for permit. 
    The cost of the annual permit shall be two percent of the annual cost of garbage and trash and waste collection service to the subject premises if furnished by the city's contract franchisee, SCA Services of Texas, Inc., based on the then current approved rates for such services and the anticipated volume and nature of wastes and the equipment and frequency of collection required for disposal, but in no event less than $25.00 for the annual permit. The city secretary shall determine the fee from information provided in the application and his investigation. If the city has or is furnished the history of collection cost from the premises during the preceding year, and the city secretary deems same reasonably indicative of collections for the application year, then the permit cost may be based on two percent of the preceding year's actual cost for collection. 
(Code 1987, § 9-6) 
Sec. 82-35. - Issuance restricted. 
    Self-collection and self-disposal permits shall be issuable only for business, commercial or industrial premises and waste disposal. No such permits shall be issued for collection and disposal of garbage, trash, waste, etc., from residential premises within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 9-7) 
Secs. 82-36-82-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CURBSIDE TRASH COLLECTION 

Sec. 82-40. - Time restrictions. 
    All trash, trash containers, bulky items, recycling containers, and grass clippings to be collected curbside shall be placed for collection not earlier than 6:00 p.m. prior to the day of scheduled collection. No trash containers or recycling containers shall be allowed to remain at the collection point after 12:00 midnight of the scheduled pick up day. 
(Ord. No. 2012-06, § 1, 1-17-12) 
Chapter 86 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, alley or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-7(4); any ordinance establishing or prescribing the street grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-7(5); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-7(7); any ordinance creating special districts or assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-7(15); buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; moving buildings, § 10-221 et seq.; peddlers, solicitors, itinerant vendors and donation seekers, § 14-211 et seq.; environment, ch. 30; flood damage prevention, ch. 38; library, ch. 46; municipal court of record, ch. 50; parks and recreation, ch. 58; planning and development, ch. 62; senior citizens center, ch. 74; signs, ch. 78; solid waste, ch. 82; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94; utilities, ch. 98; vehicles for hire, ch. 102; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. B; franchises and agreements, app. C. 
State Law reference- Municipal streets, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 311 et seq.; general municipal authority, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 311.002; control of highway assets, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 312; street improvements and assessments, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 313. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Permit required. 
    No person shall lay, construct, build, repair or rebuild any sidewalk, curb, gutter or driveway on or adjacent to any street, alley or public thoroughfare within the corporate limits of the city, or cause the same to be done by his agent, employee or private contractor, without first having obtained from the city secretary a permit. 
(Code 1987, § 18-1) 
Sec. 86-2. - Application for permit. 
    Application for the permit required by section 86-1 shall be made in writing and shall be accompanied by detailed plans and specifications of the work. Such permit shall be issued by the city secretary only after approval of the submitted plans and specifications by the city council or the city engineer or other person designated by the city council. 
(Code 1987, § 18-2) 
Sec. 86-3. - Requirements for project. 
    After the issuance of a permit for such work, all of the work shall be done according to the submitted and approved plans and specifications, and according to grades and lines furnished by the city engineer or other person designated by the city council. Such work shall at all times be subject to the inspection and approval of the city engineer or city council or other person designated by the city council for such work. 
(Code 1987, § 18-3) 
Sec. 86-4. - Certificate of inspection. 
    Immediately upon the completion of each and every such piece of work for which a permit has been issued, the contractor and the owner of the premises shall immediately obtain from the city engineer or other designated official of the city a certificate of inspection, stating in substance that such work has been completed according to the plans and specifications, grades and lines as above required. 
(Code 1987, § 18-4) 
Sec. 86-5. - Inspection. 
    In passing upon plans and specifications submitted for the work described, the council, the city engineer or other designated person shall ascertain that the contemplated work provides for proper drainage and conforms to existing sidewalks, curbs, gutters and driveways on adjoining premises. 
(Code 1987, § 18-5) 
Sec. 86-6. - Special permit required for certain driveways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or construct any driveway across or over any drainage ditch or other drainage structure along and in any public street or thoroughfare without first obtaining a permit from the city secretary. A permit shall not be necessary for the construction of a driveway in the form of a dip across the drainage ditch or structure, the surface of which driveway is no higher than the bottom of the ditch which it crosses, if such driveway and the construction thereof does not obstruct or interfere with the free flow of water through the drainage ditch which it crosses. 
(b)  Application for a permit shall be made in writing, and shall be accompanied by a fee of $5.00. 
(c)  All work, and particularly installation of any type of culvert across or in any drainage ditch, shall be pursuant to plans and specifications approved by the city engineer. The city council may require a bond in advance to guarantee the proper performance of such work. 
(Code 1987, § 18-6) 
Secs. 86-7-86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-31. - Obstruction of streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to obstruct, block, blockade or barricade any public street or thoroughfare in the city or to do anything to interfere with the free flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic. This shall not apply to the lawful use of roadways by vehicles and pedestrians, and shall not prevent the direction of traffic by authorized persons. 
(Code 1987, § 18-21) 
Sec. 86-32. - Obstruction of drainage structures in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or block any drainage ditch or other drainage structure adjacent to or across any public street or alley in the city so as to interfere with the flow of water therein. 
(Code 1987, § 18-22) 
Sec. 86-33. - Damaging streets; permits for certain excavations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or wilfully damage the surface of any public street or alley in the city or to dig or excavate. Excavations in streets to connect with sewer and waterlines, or other utilities may be made pursuant to permits issued by the city secretary. Application for such permit shall be in writing, and shall be accompanied by a fee of $5.00. The work shall be done at such time and in such manner as the city through its duly authorized officials may direct. Upon completion of any such excavation, the person making the excavation shall restore the street surface to its original condition. The city may require a performance bond in advance, to guarantee the proper performance of such work. 
(Code 1987, § 18-23) 
Sec. 86-34. - Utility company. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to excavations by public utility companies in the necessary construction, maintenance or repair of their utility lines. Such public utility companies shall not be required to apply for a permit to excavate for any of those purposes. Any utility company making any excavation in a public street or alley shall be expected to restore the surface to its original condition after completing its construction or repair work. If any excavation is to be left open overnight, proper safeguards to give notice to the traveling public shall be placed at the site of any such excavation by the utility company in accordance with instructions from the city police chief, who shall be notified in advance by the utility company that such excavation is to remain open overnight. 
(Code 1987, § 18-24) 
Secs. 86-35-86-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PAVING REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 86-51. - Paving requirements in the street right-of-way. 
    All paving within the street right-of-way in the city shall be reinforced concrete in accordance with the concrete specifications of the city. The street paving shall be not less than 28 feet face-to-face of curb and 29 feet back-to-back of curb in residential subdivisions. For collector streets in residential subdivisions, the street paving shall be 38 feet face-to-face of curb and 39 feet back-to-back of curb. For streets in all other areas, the paving shall be 44 feet face-to-face of curb and 45 feet back-to-back of curb. For thoroughfares in residential subdivisions, as well as all other areas, the paving width and specifications shall be in accordance with the city planning and zoning board and city council instructions. 
(Code 1987, § 18-36) 
Sec. 86-52. - Concrete street specifications. 
    The minimum thickness of concrete streets shall be as follows: 
     Inches 
(1)  Residential street ..... 5  
(2)  Collector street: 
a.  Residential ..... 6  
b.  Industrial and all other areas ..... 7  
(3)  Thoroughfares ..... 8  
(4)  The compressive strength shall be not less than 3,000 psi in 28 days. Where the subgrade is rock, the rock shall be removed to a depth of four inches and backfilled with acceptable sand before placement of the concrete paving. Where the subgrade is clayey soils, the soil shall be lime stabilized or cement treated base as determined by the city, to a depth of six inches before placement of the concrete paving. 
(5)  New pavement which does not meet the minimum requirements as outlined above shall be replaced at the direction of the city. The city may establish an allowable penalty policy in lieu of requiring total removal and replacement. 
(6)  The contractor shall be responsible for furnishing all laboratory tests necessary for testing new pavement. The testing laboratory used shall be under the management of a registered professional engineer. 
(Code 1987, § 18-37) 
Sec. 86-53. - Alleys. 
    Where alleys are approved, the minimum width of such alley right-of-way shall be 15 feet in residential subdivisions and 20 feet in all other areas. Curves or turns in alleys shall be wide enough to permit passage of utility or public service vehicles. 
(Code 1987, § 18-38) 
Sec. 86-54. - Specifications for alleys. 
    All such alleys shall be paved with reinforced concrete in accordance with the following minimum specifications: 
(1)  Minimum paving width, 12 feet. 
(2)  Minimum thickness: 
a.  Residential subdivisions, eight inches-five inches-eight inches (tapered). 
b.  All other areas, seven inches. 
(3)  Minimum compressive strength, 3,000 psi in 28 days. 
(Code 1987, § 18-39) 
Sec. 86-55. - Parking lots and drive areas of parking lots. 
    Parking lots and drive areas of parking lots shall be paved with reinforced concrete in accordance with the following minimum specifications: 
(1)  Minimum thickness, parking area. Four inches on six inches approved base. 
(2)  Minimum thickness, drive area. Five inches on six inches approved base. 
(Code 1987, § 18-40) 
Secs. 86-56-86-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Cost of sidewalk, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 311.096; "improvement" includes sidewalk construction, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 312.001; assessment ordinance, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 312.022. 

Sec. 86-81. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct a new residential building either multifamily or single-family within the city whether constructed on a lot zoned for residential purposes or otherwise zoned without providing for the construction of a sidewalk at least four feet in width along all street frontage of the lot on which the residential building is to be erected. Such sidewalks shall be of concrete, with at least ten gauge wire mesh reinforcing and with expansion joints at least every 40 feet and shall otherwise conform to the building code and be approved by the city building official or his designee and shall be built parallel to the curbline or street. 
(Code 1987, § 18-51) 
Sec. 86-82. - Requirement for building permit. 
    No building permit shall be hereafter issued for the construction of a new residential building within the city, unless plans for construction of the sidewalks required by this article are submitted with the building plans and permit application. 
(Code 1987, § 18-52) 
Sec. 86-83. - Requirement for occupancy permit.
