    No occupancy permit shall be hereafter issued for connection of utilities to or occupancy of any new residential building within the city unless the sidewalks required by this article have been constructed on the lot where the building is situated at the time of application for such permit. 
(Code 1987, § 18-53) 
Secs. 86-84-86-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPLOYMENT OF NETWORK NODES IN PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY 

Sec. 86-90. - Network nodes in public right-of-way. 
(a)  Generally. This article shall be construed in accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284 of the to the extent not in conflict with the Constitution and laws of the United States or of the State of Texas. To extent of any conflict between this article and the remainder of this chapter 86, this article controls. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the definitions found in the city's Design Manual for the Installation of Network Nodes and Node Support Poles are hereby incorporated into this article and shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. In addition, the definitions from V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.002 are specifically incorporated into this article by reference. In addition, in this article: 
    Chapter 284 means V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284. 
    City means the City of Saginaw, Texas. 
    City council means the governing body of the City of Saginaw, Texas. 
    Design manual means the city's Design Manual for the Installation of Network Nodes and Node Support Poles. 
    Easement means and shall include any public easement or other compatible use created by dedication, or by other means, to the city for public utility purposes or any other purpose whatsoever. "Easement" shall include a private easement used for the provision of utilities. 
    Federal Communications Commission or FCC means the federal administrative agency, or lawful successor, authorized to oversee cable television and other multi-channel regulation on a national level. 
    Street means only the paved portion of the right-of-way used for vehicular travel, being the area between the inside of the curb to the inside of the opposite curb, or the area between the two parallel edges of the paved roadway for vehicular travel where there is no curb. A "street" is generally part of, but smaller in width than the width of the entire right-of-way, while a right-of-way may include sidewalks and utility easements. A "street" does not include the curb or the sidewalk, if either are present at the time of a permit application or if added later. 
    Wireless facilities mean "micro network nodes," "network nodes," and "node support poles" as those terms are defined in chapter 284. 
(c)  Use and occupancy of public rights-of-way. Pursuant to this article and subject to the design manual and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284, a wireless network provider has the nonexclusive right to use and occupy the public rights-of-way in the city for the purpose of constructing, maintaining, and operating its facilities used in the provision of wireless facilities. The terms of this article shall apply to all wireless network providers' facilities used, in whole or part, in the provision of wireless services throughout the city, including any annexed areas upon the effective date of annexation or the date the city provides the company written notice, whichever date occurs later. 
(d)  Compliance with this article, the design manual, applicable codes, and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284. All wireless network providers shall comply with the terms of this article, the terms and conditions of the city's design manual, applicable codes, and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284 
(e)  Permit applications. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284, a network provider shall obtain a permit or permits from the city to install a network node, node support pole, or transport facility in a public right-of-way. 
(2)  As required by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284, the city shall not require a network provider to perform services for the city for which the permit is sought. 
(3)  A network provider that wants to install or collocate multiple network nodes inside the municipal limits of the city is entitled to file a consolidated permit application with the city for not more than 30 network nodes and receive a permit or permits for the installation or collocation of those network nodes. 
(4)  The network provider shall provide the following information in its permit applications: 
a.  Applicable construction and engineering drawings and information to confirm that the applicant will comply with this article, the city's design manual, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284, and applicable codes; 
b.  Any additional information reasonably related to the network provider's use of the public rights-of-way to ensure compliance with the design manual and this article; 
c.  A certificate that the network nodes comply with applicable regulations of the Federal Communications Commission; and certification that the proposed network nodes will be placed into active commercial service by or for the network provider not later than the 60th day after the date of construction and final testing of each network node is completed. 
(5)  Exception. As provided in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.86, a network provider is not required to apply, obtain a permit, or pay a rate to the city for: 
a.  Routine maintenance that does not require excavation or closing of sidewalks or vehicular lanes in a public right-of-way; 
b.  Replacing or upgrading a network node or network pole with a node or pole that is substantially similar in size or smaller and that does not require excavation or closing of sidewalks or vehicular lanes in a public right-of-way; or 
c.  The installation, placement, maintenance, operation, or replacement of micro network nodes that are strung on cables between existing poles or node support poles in compliance with the National Electrical Safety Code. 
d.  The network provider or its contractors shall notify the city at least 24 hours in advance of work described in this subdivision (5). 
(f)  Installation in municipal parks and residential areas. A network provider may not install a new node support pole in a public right-of-way without the city council's discretionary, nondiscriminatory, and written consent if the public right-of-way: 
(1)  Is in a municipal park; or 
(2)  Is adjacent to a street or thoroughfare that is: 
a.  Not more than 50 feet wide; and 
b.  Adjacent to single-family residential lots or other multifamily residences or undeveloped land that is designated for residential use by zoning or deed restrictions. 
c.  In addition to the above, a network provider installing a network node or node support pole in a public right-of-way shall comply with private deed restrictions and other private restrictions in the area that apply to those facilities. 
d.  The network provider shall be further required to comply with guidelines set out in the city's design manual. 
(g)  Municipal review process by the city. 
(1)  Determination of application completeness. The city shall determine whether the permit application is complete and notify the applicant of that determination: 
a.  For network nodes and node support poles, no later than 30 days after the date the city receives the permit application; and 
b.  For a transport facility, no later than ten days after the date the city receives the permit application. 
(2)  Approval or denial of application. The city shall approve or deny a completed application after the date it is submitted to the city: 
a.  For network nodes, no later than 60 days after the date the city receives the complete application; 
b.  For network support poles, no later than 150 days after the date the city receives the complete application; and 
c.  For transport facilities, no later than 21 days after the city receives the complete application. 
(3)  Basis for denial of application. If an application is denied by the city, it shall document the basis for the denial, including the specific applicable city code provisions or other city rules, regulations, or other law on which the denial is based. The documentation for the denial must be sent by electronic mail to the applicant on or before the date that the city denies the application. 
(4)  Resubmission of denied application. The applicant may cure the deficiencies identified in the denial application. 
a.  The applicant has 30 days from the date the city denies the completed application to cure the deficiencies identified in the denial documentation. 
b.  The city shall approve or deny the revised completed application after a denial not later than the 90th day after the city receives the revised completed application. The city's review shall be limited to the deficiencies cited in the denial documentation. 
(h)  Time of installation. A network provider shall begin installation for which a permit is granted not later than six months after final approval of the application and shall diligently pursue installation to completion. The director may in their sole discretion grant reasonable extensions of time as requested by the network provider. 
(i)  Rental rates to the city. 
(1)  As compensation for the network provider's use and occupancy of the public rights-of-way, the network provider shall pay annual public right-of-way rental rates as set forth below, which shall be in lieu of any lawful tax, license, charge, right-of-way permit, use, construction, street cut or inspection fee; or other right-of-way related charge or fee, whether charged to the network provider or its contractor(s) within the city, except the usual general ad valorem taxes, special assessments and sales tax levied in accordance with state law and equally applicable to all general businesses in the city. 
(2)  Network nodes. 
a.  The annual public right-of-way rate shall be $250.00 per network node installed in the city public rights-of-way. 
b.  As provided in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.054, the city may adjust the amount of the annual public right-of-way rate not more than annually by an amount equal to one-half the annual change, if any, in the consumer price index (CPI). The city shall provide written notice to each network provider of the new rate; and the rate shall apply to the first payment due to the city on or after the 60th day following the written notice. 
(3)  Transfer facilities. The annual transfer facility rental rate shall be $28.00 monthly for each network node site located in a public right-of-way. However, no rate is required if the network provider is already paying the city an amount equal to or greater than the amount of other city right-of-way fees for access lines under V.T.C.A., Local Governement Code ch. 283 or cable franchise fees under V.T.C.A., Utilities Code ch. 66. 
(4)  Collocation of network nodes on service poles. Subject to the city's license agreement, the collocation of network nodes on city service poles shall be at a rate of $20.00 per year per service pole. 
(j)  Indemnity. As provided in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.302, a network provider shall indemnify, defend, and hold the city harmless from and against all liability, damages, cost, and expense, including reasonable attorney's fees, arising from injury to person or property proximately caused by the negligent act or omission of the network provider. The city shall promptly notify the network provider of any claims, demands, or actions ("claims") covered by this indemnity after which the network provider shall defend the claims. The network provider shall have the right to defend and compromise the claims. The city shall cooperate in the defense of the claims. The foregoing indemnity obligations shall not apply to claims arising solely from the negligence of city; however, they shall apply in the case of all claims which arise from the joint negligence of the network provider and the city; provided that in such cases, the amount of the claims for which the city shall be entitled to indemnification shall be limited to that portion attributable to the network provider. Nothing in this article shall be construed as waiving any governmental immunity available to the city under state law or waiving any defenses of the parties under state law. 
(k)  Agreement required. The city manager is authorized to require and enter into a license agreement governing a network provider's use of the public rights-of-way for any purpose authorized by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284 and in conformance with this article. 
(l)  Effect on other utilities and telecommunication providers. Nothing in this article shall govern attachment of network nodes on poles and other structures owned or operated by investor-owned electric utilities, electric cooperatives, telephone cooperatives, or telecommunication providers. 
(Ord. No. 2017-10, § 2, 9-5-17) 
Editor's note- The city's design manual for the installation of network nodes and node support poles referenced above has not been set out, but may be inspected at the city office. 
Chapter 90 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-7(7); any ordinance creating special districts or assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-7(15); any ordinance levying a sales tax or calling an election to approve the levying of a sales tax saved from repeal, § 1-7(16); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-161 et seq.; businesses, ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Residence homestead tax exemptions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13; Municipal Sales and Use Tax Act, V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 321. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Office of tax assessor and collector. 
    The duties of the office of assessor and collector of taxes are hereby imposed upon the city secretary. 
(Code 1987, § 19-1) 
Sec. 90-2. - Tax levy. 
(a)  That there is hereby levied and there shall be collected for the use and support of the municipal government of the city, and to provide an interest and sinking fund for the retirement of each series of outstanding general obligation bonds of the city, upon all property, real, personal and mixed, within the corporate limits of the city, subject to taxation, a tax of $0.49 on each $100.00 valuation of property for the tax year 2011. Said tax being so levied and apportioned for the purposes hereinafter set forth, to-wit: 
(1)  For interest and sinking funds of the city, for payment of the principal as it matures and interest as it accrues upon all outstanding general obligation bonds of the city, a tax of eighteen and 9925/10,000ths cents (18.9925) on each $100.00 valuation of property. 
(2)  For the maintenance and operation of the general government of the city (general fund), a tax of thirty and 75/10,000ths cents (30.0075) on each $100.00 valuation of property. 
(b)  All monies collected under this section are hereby appropriated and set apart for the purposes recited, and the city manager shall cause books of account to be kept so as to readily and distinctly show amounts collected and expended and on hand at any time, in each of said funds, and it is hereby made the duty of every person collecting or receiving money for the city, pursuant to the supervision and direction of the city manager, to deliver to the city and its designated officer or employee all such money so collected or received, together with a statement showing to what fund such should be deposited and from what source received. All receipts of the city not specifically apportioned by this section are hereby made payable to the general fund, unless the city council shall by resolution or ordinance otherwise direct. 
(Ord. No. 99-8, §§ 1-3, 9-21-99; Ord. No. 2004-13, §§ 1-3, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 2009-14, §§ 1, 2, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 2010-15, § 1, 9-21-10; Ord. No. 2012-14, §§ 1, 2, 9-18-12) 
Sec. 90-3. - Taxation of goods-in-transit. 
    Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.253(j), the city council hereby mandates that goods-in-transit, as defined by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.253(a)(2), shall remain subject to taxation by the city where such goods-in-transit are not exempt under other law. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 2, 10-16-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-19, § 2, adopted October 16, 2007, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as § 90-3 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 90-4-90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM 

Sec. 90-31. - Tax levy. 
    The authority and power of the city acting through its city council as its governing body shall be governed by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 302.001, which is hereby adopted, so that this city and its city council shall have the right by ordinance to levy, assess and collect taxes in any one year as may be determined necessary for current expenses and for public improvements, not to exceed 21/2 percent of the taxable property of the city for such year. 
(Code 1987, § 19-16) 
State constitution reference- Ad valorem tax levy in cities over 5,000 population, art. XI, § 5. 
Sec. 90-32. - Delinquent taxes-Penalty and interest. 
    All taxes on real and personal property owing to the city that remain delinquent on July 1 of the year in which they become delinquent shall incur an additional penalty in the amount of 15 percent of the taxes, penalty and interest due on July 1 of the year they become delinquent to defray costs of collection. 
(Code 1987, § 19-17) 
Sec. 90-33. - Same-Lien. 
    A lien shall attach to the property on which the tax is imposed to secure that payment of the penalty, as well as the delinquent taxes and other lawful penalties and interest as provided by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.07. 
(Code 1987, § 19-18) 
Sec. 90-34. - Same-Notice. 
    The tax collector shall deliver a notice of delinquency and of the additional penalty provided by this article and V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.07, to the property owner at least 30 days and not more than 60 days before July 1 of the year the taxes become delinquent. 
(Code 1987, § 19-19) 
State Law reference- Additional penalty for collection costs, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.07. 
Secs. 90-35-90-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAX EXEMPTIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Residence homestead tax exemption, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 90-61-90-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OVER 65 YEARS OF AGE 

Sec. 90-81. - Homestead exemption. 
    Pursuant to article VIII, section 1-b of the Texas Constitution, and V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13, $50,000.00 of the assessed value of residence homesteads of persons 65 years of age and older, as defined in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13 and V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.41, shall be exempt from city real property taxes when such taxes are levied and approved by the city council upon the owner's compliance with the following: 
(1)  The residence owner shall be 65 years of age or older during the tax year; 
(2)  The residence owner shall be an actual occupant of the homestead on which the exemption is claimed, within the provisions of V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13; 
(3)  The residence owner of the homestead shall submit to the chief appraiser an exemption application form as required by V.T.C.A., Tax Code, showing that the person is qualified under subsection (1) and is an occupant under subsection (2); and 
(4)  Any other lawful requirements as may be included in the tax levy ordinance. 
(Code 1987, § 19-41; Ord. No. 2007-02, § 1, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 90-82. - One exemption granted each homestead. 
    Only one exemption under this division shall be granted for a homestead for any tax year. Joint or community owners may not each receive the same exemption provided by or pursuant to this division for the same residence homestead in the same year. 
(Code 1987, § 19-42) 
Sec. 90-83. - Ownership. 
    If a person who qualifies for an exemption as provided in this division is not the sole owner of the property to which the exemption applies, the amount of the exemption is calculated on the basis of the value of the property interest the person owns. Community ownership by a person who qualifies for the exemption and his spouse is treated as if the person owns the community interest of his spouse. 
(Code 1987, § 19-43) 
Sec. 90-84. - Penalty for false affidavit. 
    Any person who makes a false affidavit in claiming a homestead exemption under this division shall be subject to all interest charges and penalties which accrue for lack of payment of taxes for which exemption is thereby given and any other appropriate criminal penalties. 
(Code 1987, § 19-44) 
Sec. 90-85. - Additional property exemption. 
    All of that property described in the Texas Constitution, article VIII, section 1-j, as being subject to such exemption, shall be exempt from taxation in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 19-45) 
Secs. 90-86-90-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISABLED PERSONS 

Sec. 90-101. - Tax exemption granted. 
    Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13, $30,000.00 of the assessed value of resident homesteads of disabled persons, as defined in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13, shall be exempt from city real property taxes when taxes are levied for the year as approved by the city council upon an owner's compliance with the following: 
(1)  That the resident owner shall be disabled on January 1 of the tax year; 
(2)  That such resident owner shall be an actual occupant of the homestead on which the exemption is claimed, within the provisions of V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13; 
(3)  That such resident owner of the homestead shall submit to the chief appraiser before May 1 of the tax year, an affidavit and other satisfactory proof that he or she is under a disability for purposes of payment of insurance benefits under Federal Old-Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance; 
(4)  Any other lawful requirements as may be included in the tax levy ordinance. 
(Code 1987, § 19-56) 
Sec. 90-102. - Eligibility. 
    Joint or community owners may not each receive the same exemption provided by this division, and may not receive the exemption provided by this division and at the same time receive the exemption for person or persons over 65 provided by the city. An eligible disabled person who is 65 or older may not receive both a disabled and an elderly exemption but may choose either. Only one exemption may be granted for a single homestead for any tax year. 
(Code 1987, § 19-57) 
Sec. 90-103. - Ownership. 
    If a person who qualifies for an exemption provided in this division is not the sole owner of the property, the amount of the exemption shall be calculated on the basis of the property interest owned. Community property shall be deemed owned for the purpose of this exemption by the qualifying spouse if the spouses are jointly the only owners of the homestead. 
(Code 1987, § 19-58) 
Sec. 90-104. - Penalty for falsifying exemption. 
    Any person who makes a false statement in claiming exemption under this division shall be subject to all interest charges and penalties which accrue for lack of payment of taxes for which the exemption is thereby given, and any other appropriate criminal penalties. 
(Code 1987, § 19-59) 
Secs. 90-105-90-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OCCUPATION TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Restriction on occupation tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 101.008. 

Sec. 90-131. - Levied. 
(a)  There shall be and there is hereby levied and there shall be collected from every person pursuing any occupation within the limits of the city, which occupation is taxed by the general laws of the state, an annual occupation tax equal in each instance to one-half of the state occupation taxes. The taxes shall be paid annually in advance, except where otherwise provided by the state statutes, in which event the same may be paid as is provided by the state statutes. 
(b)  There shall be levied and collected from every person pursuing occupation in the city that may hereafter be assessed an occupation tax as levied by the general laws of the state, in an amount equal to one-half of such state occupation tax, which shall be levied and collected as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1987, § 19-71) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy occupation tax on coin-operated machines, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8814; sealing of machines when tax is unpaid, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 8815. 
Secs. 90-132-90-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal hotel occupancy taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 351. 

Sec. 90-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases are, for the purpose of this article, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, defined as follows: 
    Consideration means the cost of the room, sleeping space, bed, or other facility in such hotel and shall not include the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying of such room, sleeping space, bed or other facility for occupancy. 
    Hotel means a building in which members of the public obtain sleeping accommodations for consideration. The term includes a hotel, motel, tourist home, tourist house, tourist court, lodging house, inn, rooming house, or bed and breakfast. The term does not include: 
(1)  A hospital, sanitarium, or nursing home; 
(2)  A dormitory or other housing facility owned or leased and operated by an institution of higher education or a private or independent institution of higher education as those terms are defined by V.T.C.A., Education Code § 61.003, used by the institution for the purpose of providing sleeping accommodations for persons engaged in an educational program or activity at the institution. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any room or rooms, sleeping space, bed or other facility in a hotel for any purpose. 
    Occupant means anyone who, for a consideration uses, possesses, or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms, sleeping space, bed or other facility in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit right of access, license, contract or agreement. 
    Permanent resident means any occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or rooms or sleeping space or other facility in a hotel for at least 30 consecutive days during the current calendar year or preceding year. 
    Person means any individual, company, corporation or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
    Quarterly period means the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first quarter being composed of the months of January, February and March; the second quarter being the months of April, May and June; the third quarter being the months of July, August and September; and the fourth quarter being the months of October, November and December. 
    Tax collector means the tax assessor-collector of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 19-81) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-162. - Levy of tax; rate; exceptions; use of funds. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of occupancy of any room or space furnished by any hotel where such cost of occupancy is at the rate of $2.00 or more per day, such tax to be equal to seven percent of the consideration paid by the occupant of such room to such hotel. 
(b)  No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a permanent resident so long as there is no interruption of payment for the period. 
(c)  No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
(d)  Any revenues from a tax in excess of four percent of the consideration paid by an occupant of the sleeping room to the hotel may only be used for the following purposes: 
(1)  The acquisition of sites for and the construction, improvement, enlarging, equipping, repairing, operation, and maintenance of convention center facilities including, but not limited to, civic center convention buildings, auditoriums, coliseums, civic theaters, museums, and parking areas or facilities for the parking or storage of motor vehicles or other conveyances located at or in the immediate vicinity of the convention center facilities; 
(2)  The furnishing of facilities, personnel and materials for the registration of convention delegates or registrants; 
(3)  For advertising for general promotional and tourist advertising of the city and its vicinity and conducting a solicitation and operating program to attract conventions and visitors either by the city or through contracts with persons or organizations selected by the city. 
(e)  No more than one percent of the consideration paid by the occupant of a sleeping room to a hotel may be used for the encouragement, promotion, improvement, and application of the arts, including music (instrumental and vocal), dance, drama, folk art, creative writing, architecture, design and allied fields, painting, sculpture, photography, graphic and craft arts, motion pictures, television, radio, tape and sound recording, and the arts related to the presentation, performances, execution, and exhibition of these major art forms. 
(Code 1987, § 19-82) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code §§ 156.101, 351.002(c). 
Sec. 90-163. - Collection. 
    Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel shall collect the tax imposed herein for the city. 
(Code 1987, § 19-83) 
Sec. 90-164. - Reports. 
    On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person required hereby to collect the tax imposed by this article shall file a report with the tax collector showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of tax collected on the city's behalf on such occupancies, and any other information as the tax collector may reasonably require. Such person shall pay over the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. There shall also be furnished to the tax collector of the city, at the time of payment of such tax, a copy of the quarterly tax report filed with the state comptroller in connection with the state hotel occupancy tax. 
(Code 1987, § 19-84) 
Sec. 90-165. - Additional rules and regulations. 
    The tax collector shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied herein, and shall upon reasonable notice have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article and the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 19-85) 
Sec. 90-166. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  If any person required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax imposed herein, make reports as required herein, and pay to the tax collector the tax imposed herein shall fail to collect such tax, shall fail to file such report, or shall fail to pay such tax, or if such person shall file a false report, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13 of this Code. 
(b)  If any person shall fail to file a report as required herein or shall fail to pay to the tax collector the tax imposed herein when said report or payment is due, he shall forfeit five percent of the amount due as a penalty, and after the first 30 days he shall forfeit an additional five percent of such tax. Provided, however, that the penalty shall never be less than $1.00. Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of six percent per annum beginning 60 days from the date due. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation that violates, disobeys, neglects or refuses to comply with, or that resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $10.00, and in accordance with the provisions of section 1-13 of this Code. The city may also bring suit for injunction against any person, firm or corporation that shall violate or threaten to violate any of the provisions of this article, in order to prevent a continued violation of such threatened violation. 
(Code 1987, § 19-86) 
Secs. 90-167-90-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS TAX 

Sec. 90-191. - Tax levied; rate; repeal of exemption. 
(a)  A tax is hereby authorized on all telecommunications services sold within the city. For purposes of this section, the sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telephone or other telecommunications device from which the call or other communication originates. If the point of origin cannot be determined, the sale is consummated at the address to which the call or other communication is billed. 
(b)  The application of the exemption provided for in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(a), is hereby repealed by the city as authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(b). 
(c)  The rate of tax imposed by this section shall be the same as the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales and use taxes as authorized by the legislature of the state. 
(Code 1987, § 19-91) 
Sec. 90-192. - Provisions declared cumulative. 
    This article shall be and is hereby declared to be cumulative of all other ordinances of the city, and this article shall not operate to repeal or affect any of such other ordinances. The tax provided for hereunder shall not serve as an offset to, be in lieu of or in any way reduce any amount payable to the city pursuant to any franchise, street use ordinance, Charter provision, statute or, without limitation by the foregoing enumeration, otherwise payable by any provider of telecommunications service. It is the express intent hereof that all such obligations, impositions and agreements of every kind and nature shall remain in full force and effect without reduction or limitation hereby. 
(Code 1987, § 19-92) 
Chapter 94 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing traffic and parking regulations for specific streets and locations saved from repeal, § 1-7(13); transporting of animals within the city, § 6-57; parking lots, § 10-321 et seq.; junked motor vehicles, § 30-91 et seq.; fire department vehicle right-of-way, § 34-87; permit for transportation of explosives, § 34-157; municipal court of record, ch. 50; parking regulations for parks, § 58-65; use of vehicles and transportation of goods in parks, § 58-66; transporting permit for solid waste, § 82-31 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; vehicles for hire, ch. 102. 
State Law reference- Rules of the road, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 541 et seq.; powers of local authorities, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202; penalties and costs of court, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.401 et seq.; removal of unauthorized vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 684; municipal authority to regulate parking, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 431. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Reports. 
(a)  Any person in charge of a garage or repair shop situated within the city, to which is brought any motor vehicle which shows evidence of having been involved in an accident requiring a report to be filed under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 550.061 or 550.062, or struck by any bullet, shall report the same to the police department within 24 hours after such motor vehicle is received, giving the engine number, registration number and name and address of the owner or operator of such vehicle. 
(b)  Any person, a driver of a vehicle involved in any accident, shall file with the police department a report of such accident, giving full details thereof and such report shall be for the confidential use of the police department and be subject to the provisions of the Uniform Traffic Code of the state, the provisions of the Rules of the Road (V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 541 et seq.). 
(Code 1987, § 20-104) 
Secs. 94-2-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIAL RULES FOR CERTAIN AREAS 

Sec. 94-31. - Special traffic rules for Franklin Street, Saginaw Boulevard. 
    The following rules shall apply to pedestrian and vehicular traffic on Franklin Street and Saginaw Boulevard (U.S. Highway 287) regarding the traffic signal lights at the intersection of the two streets and in front of the city fire station building facing Saginaw Boulevard at the southwest comer of the intersection: 
(1)  When the light facing approaching traffic is continuously red, traffic shall stop and remain stopped until the light changes. Traffic approaching from the west or east on Franklin Street and from the north on Saginaw Boulevard shall stop before entering the intersection. Traffic approaching from the south on Saginaw Boulevard shall stop before passing in front of the city fire station building. 
(2)  When the light facing approaching traffic is flashing amber, that is, alternately off and on, traffic shall proceed through the area with caution. 
(3)  When the light facing approaching traffic is flashing red, that is, alternately on and off, traffic shall stop and then proceed with caution, yielding the right-of-way to other traffic within the intersection or close enough to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(Code 1987, § 20-16) 
Sec. 94-32. - Unpaved public property not a public street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a motorcycle, motor scooter, motor bike, minibike, dune buggie or any motor vehicle on any unpaved public property other than a public street, or on any public sidewalk or any paved or unpaved property along a street and behind the curb or on any paved or unpaved shoulder of a public road. This shall not prohibit temporary use of the shoulder of a road in an emergency. 
(Code 1987, § 20-17) 
Sec. 94-33. - Utility easements and unpaved private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a motorcycle, motor scooter, motorbike, minibike, dune buggie or any motor vehicle on any utility easement, vacant lot, or any other unpaved private property not owned by the rider or his immediate family without having on his person express written consent of the owner of the property. 
(Code 1987, § 20-18) 
Secs. 94-34-94-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate parking, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 431. 

Sec. 94-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking means parking, sitting, or standing unattended, except the parking or standing of vehicles for the purpose of expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, freight, or merchandise, on the paved portion of any residential street, alley, parkway or boulevard. This term shall not be deemed to include vehicles or equipment required for the construction of public projects or for any work done pursuant to a permit issued by the city. 
    Residential street means any street, or any part of a street, where the property abutting both sides of the street is zoned for residential purposes, that is, having property abutting on both sides zoned single-family, and any street or portion of any street between two intersecting streets along which more than 75 percent of the structures on both sides of such street or part thereof are residential structures, whether single-family, duplex or multifamily residential buildings. No part of Saginaw Boulevard or Blue Mound Road shall be considered residential streets under this article, regardless of the zoning classification or structural occupancy of abutting property thereon. 
(Code 1987, § 20-31) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-62. - Parking of certain vehicles prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  Parking of any of the following upon any residential street, alley, parkway or boulevard is prohibited, except as authorized in subsection (b). 
(1)  A vehicle with a rated capacity of more than three-quarter-ton according to the manufacturer's classification; 
(2)  A boat; 
(3)  A trailer; 
(4)  Any combination of connected vehicles, including trailers; 
(5)  Recreational vehicles (motor homes); 
(6)  Campers on pickup trucks, if the camper is wider than the bed of the pickup; 
(7)  Construction vehicles and equipment, unless working; 
(8)  Camper trailers; and 
(9)  Farm implements or animal husbandry implements. 
(b)  Motor homes and camper trailers may be parked upon a residential street, alley, parkway or boulevard for a period not to exceed 24 hours for the purpose of loading or unloading supplies and equipment, so long as they are in compliance with other parking laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1987, § 20-32; Ord. No. 2007-03, § 1, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 94-63. - Standing for loading or unloading only in certain places. 
(a)  The chief of police shall have authority to determine the location of passenger zones and loading zones and shall erect and maintain, or cause to be maintained, appropriate signs indicating the same. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stop, stand or park said vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any placed marked as a passenger zone. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stop, stand or park said vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, or for the unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials, in any place marked as a loading zone. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 15 minutes. 
(Code 1987, § 20-33) 
Sec. 94-64. - Inoperable vehicles parking restriction. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any motor vehicle, trailer or other wheeled vehicle of any kind to park or store the same upon any public road, alley or public right-of-way within the city, for a greater length of time than 24 consecutive hours, when such vehicle is mechanically inoperable for any reason. It shall be unlawful to park any of the forbidden vehicles listed in section 94-62 for any length of time on a residential street, regardless of the condition of such prohibited vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 20-34) 
Sec. 94-65. - Operable vehicle parking restriction. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any motor vehicle, trailer or other wheeled vehicle of any kind to park or store the same upon any public road, alley or public right-of-way within the city, for a greater length of time than 72 consecutive hours, when the vehicle is mechanically operable and duly licensed. It shall be unlawful to park any of the forbidden vehicles listed in section 94-62 for any length of time on a residential street, regardless of the condition of such prohibited vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 20-35) 
Sec. 94-66. - Valid license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any motor vehicle or trailer to park or store the same at any time, or for any length of time, upon a public road, alley or any public right-of-way within the city unless there is displayed on the motor vehicle or trailer a valid state license for the motor vehicle or trailer, or other license valid under state law. It shall be unlawful to park any of the forbidden vehicles listed in section 94-62 of this article for any length of time on a residential street, regardless of the condition of such prohibited vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 20-36) 
Sec. 94-67. - Parking vehicles for sale prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park upon a public road, alley or any public right-of-way within the city any vehicle displayed for sale or for the purpose of displaying advertising. 
(Code 1987, § 20-37) 
Sec. 94-68. - Owner responsible for certain parking violations. 
    If any vehicle is found upon any public road, alley or public right-of-way in violation of any of the provisions of this article, and the identity of the driver cannot be determined, the owner or person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be held prima facie responsible for such violation. 
(Code 1987, § 20-38) 
Sec. 94-69. - Nuisances removed. 
    Any motor vehicle, trailer or other wheeled vehicle found standing or parked in or upon any public road, alley or public right-of-way within the city in violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed a nuisance. Such vehicle shall be removed by any police officer of the city and taken to police headquarters, or such other place as shall be designated for such purpose by the city council. It shall be kept in police custody until application for its redemption shall be made by the owner or his duly authorized agent. 
(Code 1987, § 20-39) 
Sec. 94-70. - Costs for removal of vehicle. 
    Any vehicle impounded under the provisions of section 94-69 may be released to the possession of the owner or his duly authorized agent, upon payment to the city of the sum of $25.00, together with all other costs of removal, towing and storage that may have accrued against said vehicle. 
(Code 1987, § 20-40) 
Sec. 94-71. - Notice to owner; sale. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police or his duly authorized officer to notify the owner of any impounded vehicle in writing of the impounding of the vehicle and the costs accruing, if such owner can be ascertained. Any vehicle so impounded that has not been redeemed within six months shall be subject to public sale at auction as unclaimed property. 
(Code 1987, § 20-41) 
Sec. 94-72. - Parking on McLeroy Boulevard. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or owner of any vehicle to permit the same to be parked, stand or remain at any time upon either side of McLeroy Boulevard in the area running from the west right-of-way line of Blue Mound Road to the west boundary line of the property owned by the United States government, situated on the south side of McLeroy Boulevard, now occupied by Bell Aircraft Corporation. 
(Code 1987, § 20-42) 
Sec. 94-73. - Signs. 
    The chief of police is hereby vested with authority to erect and place signs, markings and directions for the orderly parking of motor vehicles in public parks and upon public grounds surrounding public buildings of the city in order to eliminate traffic hazards and provide for the safe and orderly use of such facilities. Such authority shall include the right to forbid parking in particular areas and to erect signs informing the public that there is no parking in particular public areas. Such authority shall also include the right to erect permanent or semi-permanent signs and directions, or temporary signs and directions when particular crowds are anticipated for particular events. 
(Code 1987, § 20-43) 
Sec. 94-74. - Obedience to signs required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing any motor vehicle in or upon any public park or public grounds surrounding any public buildings of the city within the city, in a manner violative of the plain meaning of any sign, direction or marking installed by authority of the chief of police forbidding or otherwise regulating parking of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1987, § 20-44) 
Sec. 94-75. - Parking rules for fire station. 
    The following regulations shall apply to parking of vehicles in front of or behind the fire station building in the city: 
(1)  No vehicles shall be parked at any time in front of the city fire station building, either on Saginaw Boulevard or on the paved area between the station and Saginaw Boulevard, except city fire department vehicles or other expressly authorized vehicles on fire department business. 
(2)  No vehicles shall be parked at any time on the paved parking area immediately behind the city fire station building for the full width of the station building or within the full depth of the city's paved parking area to the west of the station building, except authorized vehicles of authorized personnel of the city or expressly authorized vehicles on fire department business. 
(Code 1987, § 20-45) 
Sec. 94-76. - Areas designated for disabled persons. 
(a)  Upon the direction of the city council as to parking areas along public streets or on public property within the city, and upon the request of the owner or operator of any off-street parking facility within the city, the police department and/or public works department of the city is hereby authorized to designate stalls or spaces in such parking areas or facilities for the exclusive use of vehicles which display a distinguishing license plate, specially designed symbols, tags or other devices, issued pursuant to V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 502.253 and 502.254 and ch. 681, to disabled veterans and disabled persons for display on their vehicles. Such reserved spaces or stalls shall be designated by posting immediately adjacent to and visible from each such reserved stall or space a sign consisting of a profile view of a wheelchair with occupant in white on a blue background. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle not displaying such distinguishing license plate, tag or symbol issued to disabled veterans or disabled persons pursuant to V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 502.253 and 502.254 and ch. 681, to stop, stand or park, or leave standing such undesignated vehicle in any parking space or stall properly designated for the exclusive use of physically handicapped persons. 
(c)  Any vehicle not displaying the proper license plate, tags or devices and left within such reserved parking stalls or spaces, may be towed from any such designated disabled parking space on the direction of the police department, at the expense of the owner of such unauthorized vehicle, and may be impounded until all towing and storage charges therefor are paid. 
(Code 1987, § 20-46) 
Secs. 94-77-94-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPEED LIMITS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Speed limit in urban district, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.352(b)(1); authority to alter speed limits, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.356. 

Sec. 94-101. - Designated; exceptions. 
(a)  Twenty miles per hour is hereby established as the maximum speed limit for vehicle travelling upon all public roads within the city unless a greater rate of speed is established by order of the city council and designated by authorized signs placed upon a particular public road. This section shall not apply to U.S. Highway Nos. 81 and 287 or Farm to Market Highway No. 156 (Blue Mound Road) within the city. Permissible speeds upon those two highways shall be governed by applicable regulations of the city. 
(b)  The speed of 20 miles per hour is hereby determined by the city council to be the maximum safe speed for vehicles travelling upon all of the aforesaid public streets within the city except Highway Nos. 81 and 287 and Highway No. 156 unless the city council shall order the posting of signs otherwise directing a different speed as to a particular street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 20-61) 
Sec. 94-102. - Thompson Drive and West Southern Street. 
    The speed of 20 miles per hour is established as the maximum speed limit for vehicles travelling upon Thompson Drive and upon West Southern Street within the city. This speed limit shall cover the entire length of both streets within the city. 
(Code 1987, § 20-62) 
Sec. 94-103. - McLeroy Boulevard. 
(a)  Thirty-five miles per hour is hereby established as the maximum speed limit for vehicles traveling upon East McLeroy Boulevard in the city. 
(b)  East McLeroy, refers to that portion of McLeroy within the corporate limits of the city between U.S. Highway No. 81-287 (Saginaw Boulevard) on the west and State Farm to Market Road No. 156 (Blue Mound Road) on the east. 
(Code 1987, § 20-63) 
Sec. 94-104. - Loop 496. 
(a)  Speed limits on Loop 496, also known as U.S. Highway Nos. 81 and 287, Business Route, and known locally as Saginaw Boulevard in Tarrant County, shall be as follows: 
(1)  From Station 224+10 (north city limits of Saginaw) southerly 1.744 miles to Station 132+05 at 50 miles per hour; 
(2)  From Station 132+05 (approximately 350 feet northwest of West Northern Avenue) southerly 1.348 miles to Station 61+01 (south city limits of Saginaw, being also the north city limits of Fort Worth) at 40 miles per hour; 
(3)  From Station 142+60 (approximately 200 feet northwest of Minton Road) southerly 0.200 mile to Station 132+05 at 55 miles per hour; 
(4)  From Station 118+85 (approximately 210 feet northwest of Worth Street) southerly 0.401 mile to Station 97+80 at 40 miles per hour; 
(5)  From Station 97+80 (approximately 60 feet south of West Silliman Avenue) southerly 0.697 mile to Station 61+01 (south city limits of Saginaw, being also the north city limits of Fort Worth) at 40 miles per hour; 
(6)  From Station 71+45 southerly 0.197 mile to Station 61+01 (south city limits of Saginaw) at 40 miles per hour; 
(7)  From Station 81+95 (approximately 50 feet south of Palomino Drive) southerly 0.397 mile to Station 61+01 (south city limits of Saginaw, being also the north city limits of Fort Worth) at 40 miles per hour. 
(b)  The speed limits hereinabove set forth shall apply only to Loop 496 (also known as U.S. Highway Nos. 81 and 287, Business Route) within the city and shall not affect speed limits heretofore existing on any other public road or highway in the city. This section shall amend only the prior ordinances regulating speed on such designated highway. 
(Code 1987, § 20-64) 
Sec. 94-105. - Farm to Market Road 156. 
(a)  West lane only. The following are the speed limits adopted for the west lane only of Farm to Market Road 156: 
(1)  From Station 41+80 (north city limits of Saginaw) southerly 1.467 miles to Station 489+25 at 55 miles per hour. 
(2)  From Station 406+00 (north city limits of Saginaw) southerly to Station 489+25, a distance of 1.467 miles at 55 miles per hour. 
(3)  From Station 489+25 (approximately 500 feet north of McLeroy) southerly to Station 146+65, a distance of 0.550 mile at 40 miles per hour. 
(4)  From Station 146+65 (approximately 90 feet south of Tyson Street) southerly to Station 81+65, (south city limits of Saginaw, being also the city limits of Fort Worth) a distance of 1.231 miles at 45 miles per hour. 
(5)  From Station 33+83 (city limits of Saginaw, being also the city limits of Fort Worth) southerly 0.013 mile crossing Fort Worth and Denver City Railroad spur to Station 33+15 (city limits of Saginaw, being also the city limits of Fort Worth) at 45 miles per hour. 
(b)  East lane only. The following are the speed limits adopted for the east lane only of Farm to Market Road 156: 
(1)  From Station 33+15 (city limits of Saginaw, being also the city limits of Fort Worth) northerly 0.013 mile crossing Fort Worth and Denver City Railroad Spur to Station 33+83 at 45 miles per hour. 
(2)  From Station 81+65 (south city limits of Saginaw, being also the city limits of Fort Worth) northerly to Station 146+65, a distance of 1.231 miles at 45 miles per hour. 
(3)  From Station 114+21 (0.859 mile north of Saginaw's south city limits) southerly 0.707 mile to Station 151+54 (0.152 mile north of Saginaw's south city limits) at 40 miles per hour. 
(4)  From Station 146+65 (approximately 80 feet south of Tyson Street) northerly to Station 489+25, a distance of 0.550 mile at 40 miles per hour. 
(5)  From Station 489+25 (approximately 500 feet north of Mcleroy Boulevard) northerly to Station 406+00 (north city limits of Saginaw) a distance of 1.467 miles at 55 miles per hour. 
(Code 1987, § 20-65) 
Secs. 94-106-94-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WEIGHT LIMITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of loads and equipment, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 621.303; concrete trucks, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 622.011 et seq.; milk trucks, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 633.031 et seq.; solid waste trucks, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 623.161 et seq. 

Sec. 94-131. - Defined. 
    The words "gross weight," as used in this article, shall mean the gross weight of all vehicles joined together and moved as a unit, including the contents; provided, however, with respect to the streets mentioned in the weight definitions provided by the laws of the state shall apply. 
(Code 1987, § 20-81) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-132. - Weight limits established. 
    Gross weight limits of trucks, trailers and other vehicles, including the contents, using the public streets within the city are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  On all streets and thoroughfares within the city that are officially designated as truck routes, the gross weight limit shall be the same as that provided by the Texas Transportation Code § 621.101 for public roads and highways outside the limits of incorporated towns and cities. 
(2)  On all streets and thoroughfares within the city not officially designated as truck routes, the gross weight limit shall not exceed five tons (10,000 pounds). 
(3)  Exceptions to section 94-132 are defined in section 94-142. 
(Code 1987, § 20-82; Ord. No. 2018-07, § 1, 6-5-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-07, § 1, adopted June 5, 2018, changed the title of § 94-132 from "Established" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 94-133. - Special permit for greater weights. 
    Special permits for greater weights to cover emergency situations may be granted by the city secretary, upon application in writing, within rules to be prescribed by the city council. Any person moving a greater weight upon a public street pursuant to such special permit shall have the written permit in the possession of the driver of any such overweight vehicle while upon a public street of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 20-83) 
Sec. 94-134. - Excess weight prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, drive, move or place upon any public street of the city or cause to be operated, driven, moved or placed on any public street of the city any truck, trailer or other vehicle, of any kind, having a gross weight in excess of the limits herein provided for the particular street, or portion of any street, upon which any truck, trailer or other vehicle is found. 
(Code 1987, § 20-84) 
Sec. 94-135. - Enforcement. 
    Any police officer of the city having reasonable cause to suspect that a vehicle is of a greater weight than that permitted by this article shall have the right and authority to direct the owner or operator of such vehicle to move it to any public or private scale within the city for the purpose of weighing the vehicle and its contents. It shall be unlawful for any such owner or operator to fail or refuse to comply with the order and direction of a police officer to take such vehicle to a public or private scale for such purpose. 
(Code 1987, § 20-85) 
Sec. 94-136. - Truck routes. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial vehicle . Any vehicle, with a gross vehicle weight in excess of 10,000 pounds or carrying capacity exceeding one ton and used for the delivery of passengers, tools, materials, or livestock. A "recreational vehicle", herein, is not considered a commercial vehicle. 
    Recreational vehicle . Personal vehicles such as boats and boat trailers, watercraft and watercraft trailers, travel trailers, pickup campers or coaches (designed to be mounted on automotive vehicles), motorized dwellings, tent trailers and the like, and all-terrain vehicles. 
    Trailer . A device without motive power designed for carrying persons, animals, or property on its own structure and to be drawn by a vehicle with motive power. The term shall include, but not be limited to, semitrailer, utility trailer, travel trailer and boat trailer. 
    Truck . "Commercial vehicle." 
    Truck routes . Routes which are designated in this article for the use of truck traffic. 
    Truck traffic . The operation of any commercial vehicle including but not limited to truck, truck tractor or combination of any truck, truck tractor, trailer, or semitrailer that are considered commercial vehicles. The operations of "recreational vehicles" are not considered to be truck traffic. 
    Vehicle . Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon water, a street or road including devices moved by an engine, a motor, a motor vehicle or by human or animal power. Vehicle includes a trailer. Devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks are not considered vehicles. 
(Code 1987, § 20-86; Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, adopted June 5, 2018, changed the title of § 94-136 from "Truck routes designated" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 94-137. - Compliance. 
    No person shall operate truck traffic upon any roads, avenues, streets or thoroughfares within the city, except on those which are designated as truck routes in section 94-138, with the exceptions as set forth in sections 94-139 and 94-140. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Sec. 94-138. - Designated routes. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following streets and thoroughfares within the city are designated as truck routes: 
(1)  Saginaw Boulevard (U.S. Business 287). 
(2)  Blue Mound Road (F.M. 156). 
(3)  Bailey Boswell Road - from F.M. 156 to Old Decatur Road. 
(4)  Longhorn Road - from Old Decatur Road to Saginaw Boulevard. 
(5)  Industrial Boulevard - from Saginaw Boulevard to F.M. 156. 
(6)  Old Decatur Road - from Bailey Boswell Road to Marine Creek Parkway. 
(7)  Fairmount Street. 
(8)  Sansom Boulevard. 
(9)  E. McLeroy Boulevard. 
(10)  Burlington Road. 
(11)  Minton Road. 
(12)  Jarvis Road. 
(13)  Defiel Road. 
(14)  Brenda Lane. 
(15)  Zephyr Road. 
(16)  Triad Boulevard. 
(17)  Watson Road. 
(18)  Lawson Road. 
(19)  Any improved road, not previously listed, that has industrially zoned property fronting both sides of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Sec. 94-139. - Proceeding directly to routes. 
    If any truck traffic originating within the city shall have, as its point of origin, a point located off a designated truck route, it shall proceed to the nearest point on a designated truck route by the most direct route as possible. If such traffic shall originate outside the city and enter the city at a point which is not on a designated truck route, it shall proceed to the nearest point on a designated truck route by the most direct route possible. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Sec. 94-140. - Departing from routes. 
(a)  Truck traffic restricted to the streets designated as truck routes may depart from such truck routes, where it is necessary for the immediate loading or unloading of property at locations situated off designated truck routes. However, such truck traffic shall not leave any designated truck route until it has reached a point on some designated truck route which is nearest the applicable place of loading or unloading by the most direct route possible. After leaving a designated truck route to load or unload, truck traffic may continue off truck routes to as many points of destination as necessary. However, if in the course of making necessary stops for loading and unloading the truck traffic shall cross a designated truck route, the truck traffic shall not again leave any designated truck route until it has reached a point on some designated truck route which is nearest to the next place of loading and unloading by the most direct route possible. 
(b)  When, under section 94-139, truck traffic originates off a designated truck route, whether inside or outside the city, and the destination of the truck traffic is nearer the origin or point of entering the city, as the case may be, than is the nearest point on a designated truck route by the most direct route possible, it shall not be necessary to proceed to the nearest designated truck route. 
(c)  Driving to a place of business in a commercially zoned area for the purpose of loading or unloading shall be a defense for driving on a non-designated truck route. 
(d)  The city manager may cause to be erected signs upon the streets which are not truck routes, which signs shall be the type to conform to the manual on uniform traffic control devices. 
(e)  The city manager may cause to be erected signs upon the streets to direct trucks to truck routes, which signs shall be the type to conform to the manual on uniform traffic control devices. 
(f)  When a street or roadway designated as a truck route is under repair or otherwise temporarily out of use, the city manager is authorized to designate alternate truck routes. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Sec. 94-141. - Justification of departure. 
    A person operating any commercial vehicle including but not limited to truck, truck tractor or combination of any truck, truck tractor, trailer, or which is not designated as a truck route by this article shall have in his possession for the inspection of police officers his log book, delivery slips or other evidence of his destination and point of origin to justify the presence of the vehicle on a street or roadway other than a designated truck route. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Sec. 94-142. - Exceptions to section 94-135. 
(a)  Emergency vehicles. 
(b)  Vehicles operated by a public utility while cruising in an assigned area for the purpose of inspecting the facilities of the public utility and/or providing maintenance service to such facilities. 
(c)  Municipal and county vehicles performing city and county business and services, school buses and church buses. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07, § 2, 6-5-18) 
Secs. 94-143-94-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 94-161. - Chief of police authorized to designate crosswalks. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized to establish and to designate and shall maintain, or cause to be maintained, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(Code 1987, § 20-101) 
Sec. 94-162. - Compliance. 
    All pedestrians shall strictly comply with the directions of any official traffic control signal and are prohibited from crossing any roadway in a business district or any designated highways where crosswalks have been installed. 
(Code 1987, § 20-102) 
Sec. 94-163. - Chief of police authorized to designate safety zones and lanes for traffic. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby empowered to establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(b)  The chief of police is also authorized to make lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 20-103) 
Secs. 94-164-94-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RAILROADS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 14; utilities, ch. 98. 

Sec. 94-191. - Speed limit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any engine, train, cars or other equipment of any kind upon any railroad or any railroad tracks within the corporate limits of the city at a greater rate of speed than 45 miles per hour. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any railroad to permit the operation of its engines, trains, cars or other equipment upon any railroad or any railroad tracks within the city at a greater rate of speed than 45 miles per hour. 
(Code 1987, § 20-116) 
Sec. 94-192. - Signal devices on future crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install any new railroad crossing over and across any public street within the city unless the railroad crossing is provided with automatic flashing signal devices to warn approaching motorists on the public street of the approach of trains on the railroad track crossing such public street. 
(Code 1987, § 20-117) 
Sec. 94-193. - Signal devices on existing crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful to hereafter maintain any railroad crossing over any public street within the city which crossing is not in existence on December 14, 1971, unless the crossing is equipped with an automatic flashing signal device to warn motorists on the public street of the approach of trains on such railroad track. 
(Code 1987, § 20-118) 
Secs. 94-194-94-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - VEHICLE WRECKER SERVICE 

Sec. 94-200. - Definitions. 
    In this article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
    Accident means any occurrence that renders a vehicle wrecked or disabled. 
    Chief of police means the chief of police of the City of Saginaw, or his designated representative. 
    City means the City of Saginaw, Texas. 
    Consent tow means the towing of a vehicle at the request of the owner or operator of the vehicle. 
    Disabled vehicle means a vehicle that has been rendered unsafe to be driven as the result of some occurrence, including, but not limited to mechanical failure or breakdown, fire or vandalism, or a motor vehicle that is in a safe driving condition but whose owner or operator is not present, able or permitted to drive so as to reasonably necessitate that the vehicle be removed by a wrecker. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self propelled. 
    Nonconsent tow means the towing of a vehicle without the prearranged knowledge and consent of the owner or operator of the vehicle. Examples include, but are not limited to, vehicles towed when the driver is incapacitated following an accident, vehicles towed when the driver has been arrested, vehicles removed from public property without prenotification of the vehicle owner, and seizures, and vehicles towed from private property without prenotification of the vehicle owner as provided by this article. 
    Nonresident wrecker operator means a wrecker or tow truck operator registered with the State of Texas who does not maintain a place of business within the corporate limits of the City of Saginaw. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Vehicle means every mechanical device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    Wrecked vehicle means a discarded, abandoned, junked, wrecked or worn out vehicle that is not in a condition to be lawfully operated on a public road. 
    Wrecker or tow truck means a vehicle designed to be used primarily for removing wrecked or disabled vehicles which is equipped with a mechanical device used to tow, winch, or otherwise move a vehicle, and which charges a fee for its services. 
    Wrecker or tow truck operator means a person engaged in the business of using a wrecker to tow, winch or otherwise move a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-201. - Requirements. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person operates or employs or engages another to drive, or operate any wrecker over any street in the city for the purpose of engaging in a nonconsent tow, except as provided by this article. 
(b)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution of a violation of subsection (a) hereof that the person is engaging in: 
(1)  The transportation of a vehicle by a nonresident wrecker operator from some point outside the city to some destination within the city; 
(2)  The transportation of a vehicle by a nonresident wrecker operator from some point outside the city and traversing the city to some other destination outside of the city; 
(3)  The transportation of a vehicle by a wrecker operator at the request or with the consent of the owner or operator of that vehicle (consent tow); 
(4)  The transportation of a vehicle from the private property of another by a wrecker operator at the request of the owner of the private property (private property nonconsent tow) as provided in section 94-208; or 
(5)  The transportation of a vehicle by a wrecker service company for police nonconsent tows. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-202. - Permitted tows. 
    The towing of vehicles shall fall into one of three categories: (1) consent tow; (2) police nonconsent tow; or (3) private nonconsent tow. 
(a)  Consent tow -A tow truck requested to render service or towing for a particular person at their request. The operator of the vehicle or its owner must request this tow truck service by name. This tow truck service is not required to be on an approved listing to tow, but must have in place a tow truck tag as required by the Texas Department of Transportation or it will not be allowed to tow the vehicle. An owner's request (consent tow) may be used at the scene of an accident or on a vehicle that is abandoned, unless the officer on the scene determines that the vehicle is hazardous or that a time delay would endanger or hamper the general public's safety, well being, or the investigation. If the officer deems it necessary, a "police nonconsent tow" truck will be notified for immediate removal. 
(b)  Police nonconsent tow -This is a wrecker or tow truck called under police authority to remove or otherwise move vehicles. This contractual wrecker service may be used to tow vehicles involved in accidents where the owner is not present, or is incapacitated or otherwise unable to request a tow truck, or in situations where the operator is hospitalized or incarcerated. This service may also be used to tow vehicles being held in criminal cases as evidence, vehicles seized for forfeiture in civil actions or vehicles involved in accidents where the officer deems it necessary to remove the vehicle by police authority and nonconsent towing. 
(c)  Private nonconsent tow -A tow truck requested to remove or otherwise move vehicles on private property, without the pre-arranged knowledge or consent of the owner or operator of the vehicle, where notice of prohibited parking is given by signs or where vehicles are parked in fire lanes or obstruct an entrance, exit or aisle of a parking facility. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-203. - Wrecker service contract authorized. 
(a)  The city shall have the right to contract with one wrecker service company for all police nonconsent tows in the city, for the towing of city-owned vehicles, or for the towing of any vehicle made necessary in the exercise of city's police and governmental functions, and to store or impound such vehicles on the parking facility of such wrecker service company. 
(b)  The city may call any wrecker service company or use any wrecker in cases where the contracted wrecker service company is unable to respond as required by the contract, when there exists an emergency situation or when deemed necessary by the chief of police or his authorized representative. In all such cases, a report will be forwarded to the chief of police describing the circumstances involving such use. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-204. - Notification of police required prior to removal after accidents. 
    No damaged or inoperative vehicle shall be removed by the owner or a wrecker service company from the scene of a collision or vehicle accident without first notifying the Saginaw Police Department and receiving a consent for removal. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-205. - Prohibition of unsolicited tow truck activity; recommendations by employees. 
(a)  No person shall drive a wrecker or tow truck to or near the scene of an accident within the city unless such tow truck has been called to the scene by the owner, or his representative, of a vehicle involved, or by the police department. Each such tow truck operator, when called directly by the vehicle owner or his representative, shall notify the police dispatcher before proceeding to the scene of the disabled vehicle at the accident scene. 
(b)  No employee of the city shall recommend to any person directly or indirectly, either by word or gesture, sign or otherwise, the name of any particular person or firm engaged in the tow truck business, nor shall any city employee influence or attempt to influence, in any manner, a decision of a person in choosing or selecting a tow truck service, company or operator. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-206. - Removal of wreckage and debris. 
    Each wrecker company called to the scene of an accident shall completely remove from the street all resulting wreckage or debris, including all broken glass, before leaving the accident site. The wrecker service company will also be responsible for the absorption and removal of all liquid spills of 25 gallons or less. All liquid spills removed from accident scenes in the city shall be properly contained, stored and disposed of in accordance with applicable state and federal statutes and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-207. - Repossession or recovery towing. 
    No person or firm shall operate a tow truck business in any manner, directly or indirectly, within the city limits for the purpose of towing a vehicle without the direct and express consent of the owner of the vehicle being towed, unless that tow truck or company has made the proper notification as prescribed by law to the police department, prior to the removal of the vehicle. Proper notification is deemed as the location the vehicle is being removed from, removed by whom, removed to what location, removed by whose authority, and complete description of the vehicle, in a written manner on the prescribed form at the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § I, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 94-208. - Private nonconsent towing; required signage. 
(a)  Contractual tow trucks-Private property towing-Nonconsent towing: 
(1)  Wrecker service companies engaging in private property, nonconsent towing of vehicles pursuant to V.T.C.A. Texas Transportation Code, ch. 684, shall be licensed by the state pursuant to V.T.C.A. Transportation Code, ch. 643. 
(2)  A wrecker service company towing and/or a vehicle storage facility accepting a nonconsent towed vehicle towed from private property must report that tow to the police department. This reporting must be made within 30 minutes of removing the vehicle, giving a general description of the vehicle, the vehicle license plate number and issuing state, vehicle identification number, location from which it was removed, where it is stored, contact information of storage facility and the name of the person authorizing the vehicle to be removed.
